Current Biology, 2019; DOI: 10.1016/j.cub.2019.02.024", "channelTitle": "Bob Gymlan", "title": "Great Apes, Game Cameras, And The Bigfoot Implications"}, "id": "B-CS4tUVlvw", "statistics": {"viewCount": "84000", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "698", "likeCount": "5009", "dislikeCount": "81"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1016/j.cub.2019.02.049", "q": "10.1016/j.cub.2019.02.049", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1M37S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UCKPOSWu-b4GjEK_iOCsp4MA", "tags": ["Learning", "practice", "rest", "skillconsolidation"], "publishedAt": "2019-04-19T06:18:36Z", "description": "If you are trying to teach yourself new skills, either physical or mental, give your brain a short break during the learning process.  Neurophysiologists at the National Institutes of Health make this recommendation after analyzing the brain activity of volunteers as they master the task of reproducibly pressing a series of keys.\n\nThe scientists noted that brain wave activity which signals the cementing of behaviors into memory was more intense during short rest periods between skill practice sessions.  The subjects performed incrementally better when their initial mastery and practice sessions were interrupted by short rest periods compared with intense practice sessions followed by a night off and re-testing in the morning.\n\nSo, if you are trying to perfect a skill, learn it and practice it for awhile, then take a break, and the return to practice.  After several cycles, you should be able to optimize your performance and make it reproducible.\n\nMarlene B\u00f6nstrup, I\u00f1aki Iturrate, Ryan Thompson, Gabriel Cruciani, Nitzan Censor, Leonardo G. Cohen. A Rapid Form of Offline Consolidation in Skill Learning. Current Biology, 2019; DOI: 10.1016/j.cub.2019.02.049\n\n#Learning #practice #rest #skillconsolidation", "channelTitle": "HOWARD G. "publishedAt": "2019-05-17T20:44:03Z", "description": "Need more reasons not to use e-cigarettes and to convince your children to avoid them?  Besides the fact that they spew addicting nicotine and toxic flavoring chemicals?   A study from the Harvard School of Public Health now finds bacterial endotoxins and fungal cell wall remnants in 75 popular e-cigarette products from 10 top-selling US brands.\n\nThe investigators studied 37 e-cigarette cartridges and 38 e-liquid products that are used to refill cartridges.  They demonstrated that 23% of the products contained significant concentrations of gram-negative bacterial endotoxins and a whopping 81% of the products were contaminated with fungal by-products.  \n\nOther studies have confirmed that these bacterial endotoxins and fungal glucans trigger acute and chronic respiratory problems.  Asthmatics or those with pre-existing lung disease would be particularly vulnerable.\n\nThis study joins so many others that underscore what is just common sense: don\u2019t inhale poisons unless you have a death wish.  If the latter is the case, please get some help.\n\n\nMi-Sun Lee, Joseph G. Allen, David C. Christiani. Endotoxin and (1\u21923)-\u03b2-D-Glucan Contamination in Electronic Cigarette Products Sold in the United States. This channel is dedicated to new ideas about the nature of the sun, the stars, thermodynamics, and the microwave background.  We will discuss all things astronomy, physics, chemistry, and imaging related! We hope that the combination of facts and special effects will aid in learning even the toughest concepts in astronomy. If you enjoyed this video, please subscribe.\n\nPierre-Marie Robitaille, Ph.D., was a professor of Radiology at The Ohio State University from 1989-2019, and also held an appointment in the Chemical Physics Program. In 1998, he led the design and assembly of the world\u2019s first Ultra High Field MRI System. Readings from this equipment brought into question fundamental aspects of modern thermal physics, such as Kirchhoff\u2019s Law of thermal emission.\n\nFigures not to scale and used for visualization purposes only.\n\nThis channel is educational in nature.\n\nAstronomy links of interest:\nSpace Weather: http://spaceweathernews.com/\nNASA Image and Video Search: images.nasa.gov/\nNASA Hubble Satellite: hubblesite.org/\nNASA Helioviewer: helioviewer.org/\nNASA ADS Scientific Article Search Page: adsabs.harvard.edu/bib_abs.html\nNational Solar Observatory: nso.edu/\nSOHO Satellite: soho.nascom.nasa.gov/\nSDO Satellite: sdo.gsfc.nasa.gov/data/\nIRIS Satellite: https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/iris/index.html\nHinode, JAXA/NASA: https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/hinode/index.html\nDaniel K. This channel is dedicated to new ideas about the nature of the sun, the stars, thermodynamics, and the microwave background.  We will discuss all things astronomy, physics, chemistry, and imaging related! We hope that the combination of facts and special effects will aid in learning even the toughest concepts in astronomy. If you enjoyed this video, please subscribe.\n\nPierre-Marie Robitaille, Ph.D., was a professor of Radiology at The Ohio State University from 1989-2019, and also held an appointment in the Chemical Physics Program. In 1998, he led the design and assembly of the world\u2019s first Ultra High Field MRI System. This channel is dedicated to new ideas about the nature of the sun, the stars, thermodynamics, and the microwave background.  We will discuss all things astronomy, physics, chemistry, and imaging related! We hope that the combination of facts and special effects will aid in learning even the toughest concepts in astronomy. If you enjoyed this video, please subscribe.\n\nPierre-Marie Robitaille, Ph.D., was a professor of Radiology at The Ohio State University from 1989-2019, and also held an appointment in the Chemical Physics Program. In 1998, he led the design and assembly of the world\u2019s first Ultra High Field MRI System. Readings from this equipment brought into question fundamental aspects of modern thermal physics, such as Kirchhoff\u2019s Law of thermal emission.\n\nFigures not to scale and used for visualization purposes only.\n\nThis channel is educational in nature.\n\nAstronomy links of interest:\nSpace Weather: http://spaceweathernews.com/\nNASA Image and Video Search: images.nasa.gov/\nNASA Hubble Satellite: hubblesite.org/\nNASA Helioviewer: helioviewer.org/\nNASA ADS Scientific Article Search Page: adsabs.harvard.edu/bib_abs.html\nNational Solar Observatory: nso.edu/\nSOHO Satellite: soho.nascom.nasa.gov/\nSDO Satellite: sdo.gsfc.nasa.gov/data/\nIRIS Satellite: https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/iris/index.html\nHinode, JAXA/NASA: https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/hinode/index.html\nDaniel K. This channel is dedicated to new ideas about the nature of the sun, the stars, thermodynamics, and the microwave background.  We will discuss all things astronomy, physics, chemistry, and imaging related! We hope that the combination of facts and special effects will aid in learning even the toughest concepts in astronomy. If you enjoyed this video, please subscribe.\n\nPierre-Marie Robitaille, Ph.D., was a professor of Radiology at The Ohio State University from 1989-2019, and also held an appointment in the Chemical Physics Program. In 1998, he led the design and assembly of the world\u2019s first Ultra High Field MRI System. Readings from this equipment brought into question fundamental aspects of modern thermal physics, such as Kirchhoff\u2019s Law of thermal emission.\n\nFigures not to scale and used for visualization purposes only.\n\nThis channel is educational in nature.\n\nAstronomy links of interest:\nSpace Weather: http://spaceweathernews.com/\nNASA Image and Video Search: images.nasa.gov/\nNASA Hubble Satellite: hubblesite.org/\nNASA Helioviewer: helioviewer.org/\nNASA ADS Scientific Article Search Page: adsabs.harvard.edu/bib_abs.html\nNational Solar Observatory: nso.edu/\nSOHO Satellite: soho.nascom.nasa.gov/\nSDO Satellite: sdo.gsfc.nasa.gov/data/\nIRIS Satellite: https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/iris/index.html\nHinode, JAXA/NASA: https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/hinode/index.html\nDaniel K. We will discuss all things astronomy, physics, chemistry, and imaging related! We hope that the combination of facts and special effects will aid in learning even the toughest concepts in astronomy. If you enjoyed this video, please subscribe.\n\nPierre-Marie Robitaille, Ph.D., was a professor of Radiology at The Ohio State University from 1989-2019, and also held an appointment in the Chemical Physics Program. In 1998, he led the design and assembly of the world\u2019s first Ultra High Field MRI System. Readings from this equipment brought into question fundamental aspects of modern thermal physics, such as Kirchhoff\u2019s Law of thermal emission.\n\nFigures not to scale and used for visualization purposes only.\n\nThis channel is educational in nature.\n\nAstronomy links of interest:\nSpace Weather: http://spaceweathernews.com/\nNASA Image and Video Search: images.nasa.gov/\nNASA Hubble Satellite: hubblesite.org/\nNASA Helioviewer: helioviewer.org/\nNASA ADS Scientific Article Search Page: adsabs.harvard.edu/bib_abs.html\nNational Solar Observatory: nso.edu/\nSOHO Satellite: soho.nascom.nasa.gov/\nSDO Satellite: sdo.gsfc.nasa.gov/data/\nIRIS Satellite: https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/iris/index.html\nHinode, JAXA/NASA: https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/hinode/index.html\nDaniel K. This channel is dedicated to new ideas about the nature of the sun, the stars, thermodynamics, and the microwave background.  We will discuss all things astronomy, physics, chemistry, and imaging related! We hope that the combination of facts and special effects will aid in learning even the toughest concepts in astronomy. If you enjoyed this video, please subscribe.\n\nPierre-Marie Robitaille, Ph.D., was a professor of Radiology at The Ohio State University from 1989-2019, and also held an appointment in the Chemical Physics Program. In 1998, he led the design and assembly of the world\u2019s first Ultra High Field MRI System. Readings from this equipment brought into question fundamental aspects of modern thermal physics, such as Kirchhoff\u2019s Law of thermal emission.\n\nFigures not to scale and used for visualization purposes only.\n\nThis channel is educational in nature.\n\nAstronomy links of interest:\nSpace Weather: http://spaceweathernews.com/\nNASA Image and Video Search: images.nasa.gov/\nNASA Hubble Satellite: hubblesite.org/\nNASA Helioviewer: helioviewer.org/\nNASA ADS Scientific Article Search Page: adsabs.harvard.edu/bib_abs.html\nNational Solar Observatory: nso.edu/\nSOHO Satellite: soho.nascom.nasa.gov/\nSDO Satellite: sdo.gsfc.nasa.gov/data/\nIRIS Satellite: https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/iris/index.html\nHinode, JAXA/NASA: https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/hinode/index.html\nDaniel K. If you enjoyed this video, please subscribe.\n\nPierre-Marie Robitaille, Ph.D., was a professor of Radiology at The Ohio State University from 1989-2019, and also held an appointment in the Chemical Physics Program. In 1998, he led the design and assembly of the world\u2019s first Ultra High Field MRI System. Readings from this equipment brought into question fundamental aspects of modern thermal physics, such as Kirchhoff\u2019s Law of thermal emission.\n\nFigures not to scale and used for visualization purposes only.\n\nThis channel is educational in nature.\n\nAstronomy links of interest:\nSpace Weather: http://spaceweathernews.com/\nNASA Image and Video Search: images.nasa.gov/\nNASA Hubble Satellite: hubblesite.org/\nNASA Helioviewer: helioviewer.org/\nNASA ADS Scientific Article Search Page: adsabs.harvard.edu/bib_abs.html\nNational Solar Observatory: nso.edu/\nSOHO Satellite: soho.nascom.nasa.gov/\nSDO Satellite: sdo.gsfc.nasa.gov/data/\nIRIS Satellite: https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/iris/index.html\nHinode, JAXA/NASA: https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/hinode/index.html\nDaniel K. This channel is dedicated to new ideas about the nature of the sun, the stars, thermodynamics, and the microwave background.  We will discuss all things astronomy, physics, chemistry, and imaging related! We hope that the combination of facts and special effects will aid in learning even the toughest concepts in astronomy. If you enjoyed this video, please subscribe.\n\nPierre-Marie Robitaille, Ph.D., was a professor of Radiology at The Ohio State University from 1989-2019, and also held an appointment in the Chemical Physics Program. In 1998, he led the design and assembly of the world\u2019s first Ultra High Field MRI System. "10.3847/2041-8213/ab0e85", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT9M9S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UCuPphnMMTU_G8CDNG59jrJg", "tags": ["M87", "agujero negro", "BH", "EHT", "event", "horizon", "telescope", "telescopio", "horizonte", "sucesos", "foto", "galaxia", "sagitario A", "via lactea", "interferometria", "alma", "ESO", "agujero", "negro", "IAA", "CSIC", "IRAM", "simulacion", "imagen"], "publishedAt": "2019-04-19T22:49:52Z", "description": "El mi\u00e9rcoles 10 de abril de 2019 se dio a conocer la primera fotograf\u00eda de la sombra de un agujero negro en la historia: un hallazgo fruto del trabajo de m\u00e1s de 200 cient\u00edficos de todo el mundo, colaborando juntos para tomar los datos con una serie de antenas distribuidas por todo el globo que se juntan para formar el Event Horizon Telescope. Tras el an\u00e1lisis de la enorme cantidad de datos, obtenemos una bonita imagen donde se aprecia la sombra del horizonte de sucesos del agujero negro de la galaxia M87. Pero a\u00fan han quedado algunas dudas sobre la imagen como: \u00bfpor qu\u00e9 esta galaxia y no el agujero negro de la V\u00eda L\u00e1ctea?, \u00bfse estudiar\u00e1n m\u00e1s fuentes? o \u00bfqu\u00e9 es un telescopio virtual?. En este v\u00eddeo damos respuesta a 5 de estas preguntas.\n\n### Referencias:\n - P\u00e1gina web oficial del EHT: https://eventhorizontelescope.org/\n - Noticia del Instituto de Astrof\u00edsica de Andaluc\u00eda: https://www.iaa.csic.es/noticias/astronomos-captan-primera-imagen-agujero-negro?fbclid=IwAR25ZoGrakWGpM4I6BqZNiN2xqLYaeT\\_x9UFYCKMrSqYvPPrFQY32\\_7D6Fw\n - Rueda de prensa de presentaci\u00f3n en Madrid: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=y80_lQKTNYk\n - Interferometr\u00eda explicada con el observatorio ALMA: https://www.eso.org/public/spain/teles-instr/alma/interferometry/\n - Entrevista a uno de los investigadores del proyecto: https://www.efe.com/efe/espana/sociedad/jose-luis-gomez-csic-los-agujeros-negros-son-objetos-mas-extravagantes/10004-3951989\n - Animaci\u00f3n del agujero negro de fondo de un v\u00eddeo de la ESO: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3NeIVjfuKQY\n - Curvatura de la luz entorno al agujero negro. Animaci\u00f3n sacada de la ESO: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kc7au9Gst3U\n - Antenas que forman el Event Horizon Telescope, sacado el v\u00eddeo de su p\u00e1gina web: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MTqEeW6Q50Q\n - Animaci\u00f3n de la longitud de onda variable extra\u00edda de la p\u00e1gina del EHT. Cr\u00e9dito: Chi-Kwan Chan: https://eventhorizontelescope.org/simulations-gallery\n - Se muestran las 4 fotos obtenidas en los 4 d\u00edas de observaci\u00f3n del agujero negro de M87. En el paper es la Figura 15. Link al paper IV: https://iopscience-event-horizon.s3.amazonaws.com/article/10.3847/2041-8213/ab0e85/The_Event_Horizon_Telescope_Collaboration_2019_ApJL_875_L4.pdf", "channelTitle": "Ciencia XL", "title": "5 respuestas sobre la foto del agujero negro de M87"}, "id": "S1VDj3mv7fc", "statistics": {"viewCount": "721", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "5", "likeCount": "56", "dislikeCount": "2"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.3847/2041-8213/ab0e8c", "q": "10.3847/2041-8213/ab0e8c", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT4M45S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UCDXXnRDfuePViOGSE1szF2w", "tags": ["space", "intelligence", "universe", "NGC 1052-DF4", "NGC 1052-DF2", "NGC 1052", "dark matter", "galaxy", "galaxies"], "publishedAt": "2019-04-22T20:03:43Z", "defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "description": "In 2018, a Yale-led team of researchers published its first study about galaxy NGC 1052-DF2, the first known galaxy to contain little or no dark matter. The finding was highly significant because it showed that dark matter is not always associated with traditional matter on a galactic scale. It also ruled out several theories that said dark matter is not a substance but a manifestation of the laws of gravity on a cosmic scale.\n\nInvisible dark matter typically dominates the makeup of galaxies. Finding an object without dark matter was unprecedented and led to a good deal of debate within the scientific community.\n\n\u201cIf there\u2019s one object, you always have a little voice in the back of your mind saying, \"but what if you\u2019re wrong?\u2019\u201d said team leader Pieter van Dokkum, the Sol Goldman Family Professor of Astronomy at Yale. \u201cEven though we did all the checks we could think of, we were worried that nature had thrown us for a loop and had conspired to make something look really special whereas it was really something more mundane.\u201d\n\nNow, a pair of new studies appearing in The Astrophysical Journal Letters supports the team\u2019s initial finding.\n\nYale graduate student Shany Danieli, who first spotted the galaxy about two years ago, is the lead author of one of the new studies (https://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.3847/2041-8213/ab0e8c). It confirms the team\u2019s initial observations of DF2, using more precise measurements from the W.M. Keck Observatory\u2019s Keck Cosmic Web Imager. The researchers found that the stars inside the galaxy are moving at a speed consistent with the mass of the galaxy\u2019s normal matter. If there were dark matter in DF2, the stars would be moving much faster.\n\nVan Dokkum is lead author of the other new study (https://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.3847/2041-8213/ab0d92/meta), which details the discovery of a econd galaxy devoid of dark matter. That galaxy is named DF4.\n\n\u201cDiscovering a second galaxy with very little to no dark matter is just as exciting as the initial discovery of DF2,\u201d van Dokkum said. \u201cThis means the chances of finding more of these galaxies are now higher than we previously thought. Since we have no good ideas for how these galaxies are formed, I hope these discoveries will encourage more scientists to work on this puzzle.\u201d\n\nBoth DF2 and DF4 are part of a relatively new class of galaxies called ultra-diffuse galaxies (UDGs). They are as large as the Milky Way but have between 100 to 1,000 times fewer stars. This makes them appear fluffy and translucent \u2014 and difficult to observe.\n\nIronically, the lack of dark matter in these UDGs strengthens the case for dark matter, the researchers say. It proves that dark matter is a substance that is not coupled with normal matter, since they can be found separately.\n\nDanieli is leading a wide area survey with the Dragonfly Telephoto Array \u2014 a telescope designed by van Dokkum \u2014 to look for more examples in a systematic way, then observe candidates again using the Keck telescopes.\n\n\u201cWe hope to next find out how common these galaxies are and whether they exist in other areas of the universe,\u201d Danieli said. \u201cWe want to find more evidence that will help us understand how the properties of these galaxies work with our current theories. Our hope is that this will take us one step further in understanding one of the biggest mysteries in our universe \u2014 the nature of dark matter.\u201d (https://news.yale.edu/2019/03/29/new-studies-confirm-existence-galaxies-almost-no-dark-matter)\n\nVideo: Hubble Views Galaxy Lacking Dark Matter https://youtu.be/2y79N4W6In8\n\nMusic: Teardrop - Massive Attack \n\nSpace And Intelligence https://spaceandai.com", "channelTitle": "Space And Intelligence", "title": "Second Galaxy Lacking Dark Matter Discovered", "defaultLanguage": "en"}, "id": In 1998, he led the design and assembly of the world\u2019s first Ultra High Field MRI System. This channel is dedicated to new ideas about the nature of the sun, the stars, thermodynamics, and the microwave background.  We will discuss all things astronomy, physics, chemistry, and imaging related! We hope that the combination of facts and special effects will aid in learning even the toughest concepts in astronomy. If you enjoyed this video, please subscribe.\n\nPierre-Marie Robitaille, Ph.D., was a professor of Radiology at The Ohio State University from 1989-2019, and also held an appointment in the Chemical Physics Program. In 1998, he led the design and assembly of the world\u2019s first Ultra High Field MRI System. \u043a\u0430\u043a \"\u0433\u0440\u0430\u0432\u0438\u0442\u0430\u0446\u0438\u043e\u043d\u043d\u044b\u0439 \u0440\u0430\u0434\u0438\u0443\u0441, \u0442\u0435\u043d\u044c "description": "Die Sensation im letzten Jahr: Harvard Professor Alexander Loeb meint, dass das Interstellare Objekt 1I Oumuamua eine Alien-Sonde sein k\u00f6nnte. Fakt war: das Objekt wurde so stark von Sonnenwinden beschleunigt, dass das nur mit der Beschaffenheit eines Sonnensegels erkl\u00e4rt werden konnte. Das Objekt musste extrem d\u00fcnn und leicht sein. Ein nat\u00fcrlicher Ursprung w\u00e4re damit unwahrscheinlich. Und jetzt gibt es eine weitere Studie und auch die sagt: es ist ein Sonnensegel! In 1998, he led the design and assembly of the world\u2019s first Ultra High Field MRI System. If you enjoyed this video, please subscribe.\n\nPierre-Marie Robitaille, Ph.D., was a professor of Radiology at The Ohio State University from 1989-2019, and also held an appointment in the Chemical Physics Program. In 1998, he led the design and assembly of the world\u2019s first Ultra High Field MRI System. This channel is dedicated to new ideas about the nature of the sun, the stars, thermodynamics, and the microwave background. If you enjoyed this video, please subscribe.\n\nPierre-Marie Robitaille, Ph.D., was a professor of Radiology at The Ohio State University from 1989-2019, and also held an appointment in the Chemical Physics Program. In 1998, he led the design and assembly of the world\u2019s first Ultra High Field MRI System. Eles desafiam muito do que sabemos (ou pensamos saber) sobre relatividade e f\u00edsica qu\u00e2ntica. S\u00f3 que tem um problema: como n\u00f3s podemos fotografar algo que n\u00e3o emite e nem reflete luz? Entenda tudo por tr\u00e1s da hist\u00f3rica primeira foto que tiramos de um buraco negro.\n\nAssine nossa campanha para manter os v\u00eddeos no ar! http://catarse.me/cienciatododia\n\nLoja Oficial do Ci\u00eancia Todo Dia: http://bit.ly/CamisetasCienciaTodoDia\n\nMinhas redes sociais:\nhttp://instagram.com/pedroloos\nhttp://twitter.com/pedroloos\n\nNosso podcast: http://anchor.fm/sinapse\n\nE-mail: contato@cienciatododia.com.br\n\nUm muito obrigado aos apoiadores do Catarse que tornaram esse v\u00eddeo poss\u00edvel: Erasmo Ribeiro, H\u00e9ctor Pittman Villarreal, Eustaquio Barbosa, Martim Bottene, Pedro Pizzolato, Silvio Barbosa, Jackson Cardoso, Patricia Guedes, Roberto Carneiro, Rapha Nascimento, Douglas Martelo e Henrique Tavitian.\n\nLeitura Adicional e Fontes:\n\nhttp://www.sciencemag.org/news/2019/04/here-s-what-scientists-think-black-hole-looks\n\nhttps://arxiv.org/pdf/1502.03808.pdf\n\nhttps://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.3847/2041-8213/ab1141\n\nhttps://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.3847/2041-8213/ab0f43\n\nhttps://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.3847/2041-8213/ab0e85\n\nhttps://iopscience.iop.org/journal/2041-8205/page/Focus_on_EHT", "channelTitle": "Ci\u00eancia Todo Dia", "title": "Essa \u00e9 a Primeira Foto de um Buraco Negro", "defaultLanguage": "pt"}, "id": "E3cIU6NbMWE", "statistics": {"viewCount": "959761", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "6269", "likeCount": "138752", "dislikeCount": "997"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.3847/2041-8213/ab1141", "q": "10.3847/2041-8213/ab1141", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT13M28S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UCL7QIOZteWPpBWBOl8i0e-g", "description": "The Event Horizon Telescope Collaboration, First M87 Event Horizon Telescope Results. \nI. We will discuss all things astronomy, physics, chemistry, and imaging related! We hope that the combination of facts and special effects will aid in learning even the toughest concepts in astronomy. If you enjoyed this video, please subscribe.\n\nPierre-Marie Robitaille, Ph.D., was a professor of Radiology at The Ohio State University from 1989-2019, and also held an appointment in the Chemical Physics Program. In 1998, he led the design and assembly of the world\u2019s first Ultra High Field MRI System. \u043b\u0435\u043d\u0438\u0432\u044b\u0439. \u041f\u043e\u0436\u0430\u043b\u0443\u0439 \u0441 10 \u0430\u043f\u0440\u0435\u043b\u044f, \u0442\u0430\u043a\u0438\u0435 \u0441\u043b\u043e\u0432\u0430 \u043a\u0430\u043a \"\u0433\u0440\u0430\u0432\u0438\u0442\u0430\u0446\u0438\u043e\u043d\u043d\u044b\u0439 \u0440\u0430\u0434\u0438\u0443\u0441, \u0442\u0435\u043d\u044c \u0447\u0451\u0440\u043d\u043e\u0439 \u0434\u044b\u0440\u044b\" \u0438\u043b\u0438 \"\u0440\u0430\u0434\u0438\u043e\u0438\u043d\u0442\u0435\u0440\u0444\u0435\u0440\u043e\u043c\u0435\u0442\u0440\" This channel is dedicated to new ideas about the nature of the sun, the stars, thermodynamics, and the microwave background.  We will discuss all things astronomy, physics, chemistry, and imaging related! We hope that the combination of facts and special effects will aid in learning even the toughest concepts in astronomy. If you enjoyed this video, please subscribe.\n\nPierre-Marie Robitaille, Ph.D., was a professor of Radiology at The Ohio State University from 1989-2019, and also held an appointment in the Chemical Physics Program. In 1998, he led the design and assembly of the world\u2019s first Ultra High Field MRI System. Roberts, and R.E. Kambic\r\nhttp://www.xromm.org/projects/avian-bipedal-locomotion\r\n\r\nXROMM animation of the pelvis and right hind limb bones of a Helmeted Guineafowl walking steadily at 0.6 m/s. The femur, tibiotarsus, and tarsometatarsus undergo subtle long-axis rotations as the limb moves through 3-D space. The playback speed is one tenth of the real speed. Animated by S.M. Gatesy, R.E. Written language only began at around 3200 BC, but spoken language has existed long ago.\r\n\r\nLearning by listening is a great way to:\r\n- increases imagination and understanding\r\n- improves your listening skills\r\n- improves your own spoken accent\r\n- learn while on the move\r\n- reduce eye strain\r\n\r\nNow learn the vast amount of general knowledge available on Wikipedia through audio (audio article). You could even learn subconsciously by playing the audio while you are sleeping! If you are planning to listen a lot, you could try using a bone conduction headphone, or a standard speaker instead of an earphone.\r\n\r\nYou can find other Wikipedia audio articles too at:\r\nhttps://www.youtube.com/channel/UCuKfABj2eGyjH3ntPxp4YeQ\r\n\r\nYou can upload your own Wikipedia articles through:\r\nhttps://github.com/nodef/wikipedia-tts\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\"The only true wisdom is in knowing you know nothing.\"\r\n- Socrates\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSUMMARY\r\n=======\r\nOpen access (OA) refers to research outputs which are distributed online and free of cost or other barriers, and possibly with the addition of a Creative Commons license to promote reuse. Open access can be applied to all forms of published research output, including peer-reviewed and non peer-reviewed academic journal articles, conference papers, theses, book chapters, and monographs.Academic articles (as historically seen in paper-based academic journals) have been the main focus of the movement. Conventional (non-open access) journals cover publishing costs through access tolls such as subscriptions, site licenses or pay-per-view charges. Open access research is advanced by a range of distribution mechanisms and business models. These include:\n\nSelf-archiving - green: After peer review by a journal, the author posts the same content the journal will be publishing to a web site controlled by the author, the research institution that funded or hosted the work, or which has been set up as a central open access repository.\nOpen access journal: The publisher of the journal makes all articles and related content available for free on the journal's web site.\nOpen access journal funded by article processing charges paid by authors or research sponsor - gold\nOpen access journal funded by an academic institution, learned society or a government information center (no publication fees are paid by authors) - platinum, diamond, or gold\nDelayed open-access journals - provide open access after an embargo period, typically 6\u201312 months or longer\nHybrid open access journals at least partially funded by subscriptions, and only provide open access for those individual articles for which the authors (or research sponsor) pay a publication feeAdvantages and disadvantages of open access have generated considerable discussion amongst researchers, academics, librarians, university administrators, funding agencies, government officials, commercial publishers, editorial staff and society publishers. Reactions of existing publishers to open access journal publishing have ranged from moving with enthusiasm to a new open access business model, to experiments with providing as much free or open access as possible, to active lobbying against open access proposals. There are many publishers that started up as open access-only  publishers, such as PLOS, Hindawi Publishing Corporation, Frontiers in... journals, MDPI and BioMed Central.", "channelTitle": "wikipedia tts", "title": "Open access | Wikipedia audio article", "defaultLanguage": "en"}, "id": "NjB2io9X_cA", "statistics": {"viewCount": "7", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "1", "likeCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1002/fee.2003", "q": "10.1002/fee.2003", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT18M44S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UCsPs4JQVxo2-IjKMs4NkZPg", "tags": ["academic journal", "academic journals", "academic publishing", "peer review", "scholarly communication", "wikipedia audio article", "learning by listening", "improves your listening skills", "learn while on the move", "reduce eye strain", "text to speech"], "publishedAt": "2018-11-20T05:14:55Z", "defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "description": "This is an audio version of the Wikipedia Article:\r\nAcademic journal\r\n\r\nListening is a more natural way of learning, when compared to reading. Written language only began at around 3200 BC, but spoken language has existed long ago.\r\n\r\nLearning by listening is a great way to:\r\n- increases imagination and understanding\r\n- improves your listening skills\r\n- improves your own spoken accent\r\n- learn while on the move\r\n- reduce eye strain\r\n\r\nNow learn the vast amount of general knowledge available on Wikipedia through audio (audio article). You could even learn subconsciously by playing the audio while you are sleeping! If you are planning to listen a lot, you could try using a bone conduction headphone, or a standard speaker instead of an earphone.\r\n\r\nYou can find other Wikipedia audio articles too at:\r\nhttps://www.youtube.com/channel/UCuKfABj2eGyjH3ntPxp4YeQ\r\n\r\nYou can upload your own Wikipedia articles through:\r\nhttps://github.com/nodef/wikipedia-tts\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\"The only true wisdom is in knowing you know nothing.\"\r\n- Socrates\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSUMMARY\r\n=======\r\nAn academic or scholarly journal is a periodical publication in which scholarship relating to a particular academic discipline is published. Academic journals serve as permanent and transparent forums for the presentation, scrutiny, and discussion of research. They are usually peer-reviewed or refereed. Content typically takes the form of articles presenting original research, review articles, and book reviews. The purpose of an academic journal, according to Henry Oldenburg (the first editor of Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society), is to give researchers a venue to \"impart their knowledge to one another, and contribute what they can to the Grand design of improving natural knowledge, and perfecting all Philosophical Arts, and Sciences.\"The term academic journal applies to scholarly publications in all fields; this article discusses the aspects common to all academic field journals. Scientific journals and journals of the quantitative social sciences vary in form and function from journals of the humanities and qualitative social sciences; their specific aspects are separately discussed.\nThe first academic journal was Journal des s\u00e7avans (January 1665), followed soon after by Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society (March 1665), and M\u00e9moires de l'Acad\u00e9mie des Sciences (1666). The first fully peer-reviewed journal was Medical Essays and Observations (1733).", "channelTitle": "wikipedia tts", "title": "Academic journal | Wikipedia audio article", "defaultLanguage": "en"}, Neurotherapeutics\n\nPresented by Jasleen Chhatwal, MD, Associate Medical Director; Director of Mood Recovery. Recorded on May 8th, 2019.\n\nApproximately a third of patients with major depressive disorder do not respond to treatment, with only half achieving remission. This results in high morbidity and makes MDD one of the leading causes of disability in the world per the World Health Organization. Early intervention, intensive and multimodal treatment are key to improving outcomes in this patient population. Challenges inherent to treatment include polymorphism in the presentation, multifactorial etiology and complex pathophysiology. In this presentation, we will review current evidence for approaching patients with difficult to treat presentations using psychotherapy, psychopharmacology, neurotherapeutics and complementary-alternative medicine. In case of a broader view, what IWRM stands for is the integrated approach that should consider ecosystem services along similar lines because when an IWRM plan decides on the allocation of water in the landscape, it inadvertently also decides on the redistribution of ecosystem services that are derived at that location. These IWR management decisions also have an impact on how regulatory ecosystems services (with mostly public interests) and provisioning ecosystem services (with more individual interest at stake) can be harnessed. Our economic minded approach on the terrestrial water cycle will help to structure all these issues of local water uses and mitigation within one frame.\n\nSPEAKERS: G\u00e1bor Ungv\u00e1ri, Senior {"channelId": "UCiKHuqqOlTW_quHoXmLx3VQ", "tags": ["gene therapy", "chromosome", "gene", "cancer", "tumor", "cell", "modification", "oncolytic", "virotherapy", "apoptosis", "prodrug", "cytotoxic", {"channelId": "UCBnHyctC62ph9p86yBM-I8A", "tags": ["open access", "academic publishing", "electronic publishing", "free culture movement", "open access (publishing)", "open access journals", "scholarly communication", "social movements", "wikipedia audio article", "learning by listening", "improves your listening skills", "learn while on the move", "reduce eye strain", "text to speech"], "publishedAt": "2018-11-28T00:16:09Z", "defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "description": "This is an audio version of the Wikipedia Article:\r\nOpen access\r\n\r\nListening is a more natural way of learning, when compared to reading. Written language only began at around 3200 BC, but spoken language has existed long ago.\r\n\r\nLearning by listening is a great way to:\r\n- increases imagination and understanding\r\n- improves your listening skills\r\n- improves your own spoken accent\r\n- learn while on the move\r\n- reduce eye strain\r\n\r\nNow learn the vast amount of general knowledge available on Wikipedia through audio (audio article). You could even learn subconsciously by playing the audio while you are sleeping! If you are planning to listen a lot, you could try using a bone conduction headphone, or a standard speaker instead of an earphone.\r\n\r\nYou can find other Wikipedia audio articles too at:\r\nhttps://www.youtube.com/channel/UCuKfABj2eGyjH3ntPxp4YeQ\r\n\r\nYou can upload your own Wikipedia articles through:\r\nhttps://github.com/nodef/wikipedia-tts\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\"The only true wisdom is in knowing you know nothing.\"\r\n- Socrates\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSUMMARY\r\n=======\r\nOpen access (OA) refers to research outputs which are distributed online and free of cost or other barriers, and possibly with the addition of a Creative Commons license to promote reuse. Open access can be applied to all forms of published research output, including peer-reviewed and non peer-reviewed academic journal articles, conference papers, theses, book chapters, and monographs.Academic articles (as historically seen in paper-based academic journals) have been the main focus of the movement. Conventional (non-open access) journals cover publishing costs through access tolls such as subscriptions, site licenses or pay-per-view charges. Open access research is advanced by a range of distribution mechanisms and business models. These include:\n\nSelf-archiving - green: After peer review by a journal, the author posts the same content the journal will be publishing to a web site controlled by the author, the research institution that funded or hosted the work, or which has been set up as a central open access repository.\nOpen access journal: The publisher of the journal makes all articles and related content available for free on the journal's web site.\nOpen access journal funded by article processing charges paid by authors or research sponsor - gold\nOpen access journal funded by an academic institution, learned society or a government information center (no publication fees are paid by authors) - platinum, diamond, or gold\nDelayed open-access journals - provide open access after an embargo period, typically 6\u201312 months or longer\nHybrid open access journals at least partially funded by subscriptions, and only provide open access for those individual articles for which the authors (or research sponsor) pay a publication feeAdvantages and disadvantages of open access have generated considerable discussion amongst researchers, academics, librarians, university administrators, funding agencies, government officials, commercial publishers, editorial staff and society publishers. Reactions of existing publishers to open access journal publishing have ranged from moving with enthusiasm to a new open access business model, to experiments with providing as much free or open access as possible, to active lobbying against open access proposals. There are many publishers that started up as open access-only  publishers, such as PLOS, Hindawi Publishing Corporation, Frontiers in... journals, MDPI and BioMed Central.", "channelTitle": "wikipedia tts", "title": "Open access | Wikipedia audio article", "defaultLanguage": "en"}, "id": "NjB2io9X_cA", "statistics": {"viewCount": "7", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "1", "likeCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1002/fee.2015", "q": "10.1002/fee.2015", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT3M24S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UCiefLm_nIz_gOH7XHbgpdCQ", "tags": ["brainstuff", "brain stuff", "howstuffworks", "how stuff works", "science", "technology", "lauren vogelbaum", "techstuff", "fw thinking", "pricing", "price", "psychology", "99 cents", "98 cents", "99", "98", "95 cents", "95", "price tag", "price tags", "psychological pricing", "nine", "ninety-nine", "cents", "odd pricing", "odd prices", "charm prices", "charm pricing", "rounding", "price point", "price points", "economics", "marketing", "sale", "sales", "advertising", "advertisement", "advertisements", "why do price tags end in .99"], "publishedAt": "2016-04-19T16:00:04Z", "defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "description": "It\u2019s very common to see the number 9 at the right end of a price tag. Why is this? Lauren explains the psychology of prices and nines in this episode of BrainStuff.\n\nLearn more at HowStuffWorks.com.\n\nShare on Facebook: \nShare on Twitter: \nSubscribe: http://goo.gl/ZYI7Gt\nVisit our site: http://www.brainstuffshow.com\n\nHi there! I\u2019m Lauren, and this is BrainStuff. The other day I was shopping at Bavmorda\u2019s Trebuchet and Millinery Emporium and I started wondering -- why do so many prices end in the number 9?\n\nYou might have wondered the same thing too, and if you have, it\u2019s not just your imagination. Studies have shown that many retailers disproportionately use prices within 5 cents of the nearest dollar, 1 cent of the nearest 10 cents, $5 of the nearest $100 or $1000, and within $1 of the nearest 10-dollar amount. \n\nPrices like this are often known as \u201ccharm\u201d prices, \u201codd\u201d prices, \u201cmagic\u201d prices, or \u201cpsychological pricing.\u201d Pricetags ending in the number 9 are especially common. But why?\n\nThese days, two main psychological theories of charm pricing have emerged. And yes, this is a field of study. For the purpose of this video, we\u2019ll call them the \u201crounding off\u201d theory and the \u201cbargain signaling\u201d theory.\n\nThe rounding off theory argues that shoppers tend to pay a lot more attention to the first digits in a listed price. So, when you see a product labels $29.99, even though it's only 1 penny off from being 30 bucks, the theory goes that you mentally round down to think of it as a $20 price point based on that first digit. \n\nFor example, a 2005 study found that prices ending in 99 cents caused shoppers to make math errors that even-dollar prices did not. It worked like this: Test shoppers were given an allowance of exactly 73 bucks, and they were then asked to estimate how many products they could buy with this allowance. It turned out that when 99-cent endings were in the picture, shoppers overestimated their spending power. \n\nIn other words, they thought they could buy significantly more products at prices like $2.99 and $5.99 than they could at $3 and $6. This seems to suggest that we do tend to \u201cround down\u201d and ignore the final digits in prices, even though it makes no economic sense to do so.\n\nThe bargain signaling theory suggests that odd prices work the same way \u201cSale\u201d signs do, meaning they imply to shoppers that the price listed is especially good. Maybe the weird specificity of something priced $5.98 or $2.39 makes us think that the store is selling that bag of Gummy Bears at the lowest price point they can possibly afford. Or maybe we\u2019ve all been conditioned by marketing to associate odd prices, especially the ones ending in 9, with sales and discounts.\n\nIn 2003, researchers showed that in some cases, you could actually increase demand for an item by raising the price so that it ended in a \u20189,\u2019 which would seem to contradict rational economics. \n\nOne example they studied: A $34 dress in a clothing catalog. By raising the price from 34 bucks to 39 bucks, demand for the dress actually went up. When they raised the price to $44, however, the trend didn\u2019t hold -- so it wasn\u2019t just that buyers liked paying more for their clothes. \n\nSince 34 and 39 both start with the same digit, this would seem to favor the bargain signaling theory rather than the rounding off theory. Something about the 9 just seemed to make people think they were getting a good deal.\n\nSo it looks like our penchant for buying at the 9s might be explained by a mixture of our tendency to round down to the leftmost digit AND our beliefs that 9s inherently indicate bargains.\n\nSOURCES:\n\nhttp://www.jstor.org/stable/10.1086/678484?seq=1#page_scan_tab_contents \n\nhttp://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2015/01/the-psychological-difference-between-1200-and-1167/384993/ \n\nhttp://timharford.com/2012/06/pound-for-pound-99p-is-worth-every-penny/ \n\nhttp://www.nytimes.com/2009/02/08/weekinreview/08arango.html?_r=0 \n\nhttp://dept.camden.rutgers.edu/business/files/Schindler-2006.pdf\n\nhttp://dept.camden.rutgers.edu/business/files/Bizer-Schindler-2005.pdf \n\nhttp://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/mar.20084/abstract\n\nhttps://hbr.org/2003/09/mind-your-pricing-cues \n\nhttp://classes.bus.oregonstate.edu/fall-05/ba499/elton/Articles/Mind%20Your%20Pricing%20Cues.pdf \n\nhttp://link.springer.com/article/10.1023%2FA%3A1023581927405\n\nhttp://www.ozshy.50webs.com/21why99.pdf \n\nhttps://www_nelsonpricing_com_ar.1.com.ar/biblioteca_pricing/1997-02_why_are_so_many_goods_priced_to_end_in_nine_Basu_K.pdf \n\nhttp://marketing-bulletin.massey.ac.nz/V8/MB_V8_N1_Holdershaw.pdf", "channelTitle": "BrainStuff - Gates, Monomolecular and bimolecular mechanisms of paraffin cracking: n-butane cracking catalyzed by HZSM-5, Journal of Catalysis, Volume 135, Issue 1, 1992, Pages 115-124, ISSN 0021-9517, https://doi.org/10.1016/0021-9517(92)90273-K.\n(http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/002195179290273K)\n\nDifferent Hydrocracking Catalysts by UOP\n\nhttps://www.uop.com/products/catalysts/hydroprocessing/", "channelTitle": "Theo Ong", "title": "Petroleum Downstream Crash Course 23 - Hydrocracking Fundamentals"}, "id": "dmqmf_f_CEU", "statistics": {"viewCount": "5727", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "1", "likeCount": "59", "dislikeCount": "4"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1002/fee.2015", "q": "10.1002/fee.2015", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT39M37S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UCCzBFhzRC0vdYVL5KuS9pHg", "tags": ["sustainability standards", "C\u00f4te d'Ivoire", "cooperatives", "cocoa", "agriculture"], "publishedAt": "2020-08-05T10:49:27Z", "defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "description": "ZEF online colloquium\nJune 18, 2020\n\nSustainability standards such as Fairtrade, UTZ, and Rainforest Alliance have been gaining importance in global value chains, with some of the major tropical commodities seeing significant increases in the share of their certified area in the last ten years. Despite differences in their requirements and the extent to which they focus on socioeconomic and environmental goals, all major sustainability standards claim that they are beneficial to farmers and workers in the small farm sector.\nAlthough the growing body of literature that seeks to evaluate these claims is already rather comprehensive in terms of the standards, countries, crops and outcome variables it focuses on, it still has some shortcomings that need to be addressed. Most notably, it has not paid enough attention to the role that agricultural cooperatives might have in determining whether and to what extent farmers and workers benefit from participating in certified value chains. In this seminar, he will present the results of two studies that have been conducted using data from 1,000 farmers and workers randomly sampled from 50 cocoa cooperatives in C\u00f4te d\u2019Ivoire. First, he discusses the importance of using a sampling design that sufficiently accounts for institutional heterogeneity in agricultural cooperatives and analyze whether farmer households benefit economically from Fairtrade certification once we control for cooperative effects. Second, he analyzes whether Fairtrade causes changes in agrochemical input use and what are its effects on aggregated pesticide toxicity and on the incidence of pesticide-related acute health symptoms among farmers and workers. He argues that cooperatives do matter in the analysis of sustainability standards and that future studies should give more explicit focus to cooperative heterogeneity, both in their sampling strategies and in their empirical analyses.\nThis presentation is based on the following two papers:\n\u2022 https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1002/ajae.12015 \n\u2022 https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0921800920303566 \n\nSpeaker: \nDr. Jorge Sellare is a Senior Researcher at ZEF and he his currently working on Land use and food security, Growth, inequality and poverty and New Technologies and has experience in Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay, C\u00f4te d'Ivoire. reviews (and meta-analyses)?\n\nThis is module two of seven critical appraisal training videos. "Solar Cells", "Polymer", "lifetime", "stability", "materials", "advanced", "energy", "PCBM"], "publishedAt": "2017-09-11T11:32:57Z", "description": "Jordi Martorell and co-workers propose ways to achieve a long lifetime of polymer solar cells by addressing the issue and mechanism of UV-induced nano-morphology disorder.  To increase device lifetime, the authors turned to thermal annealing prior to light soaking to increase the active layer\u2019s crystalline order. The study predicts an impressive lifetime of 10 years for vertical applications and demonstrates that alongside the high power conversion efficiency of the cells, the strategy may be used in solar window technologies. To read the full article in Advanced Energy Materials, please visit: https://doi.org/10.1002/aenm.201701201", "channelTitle": "Advanced Science News", "title": "Circumventing UV light induced nano-morphology disorder to achieve long lifetime polymer solar cells"}, "id": "glw1fHxyBYY", "statistics": {"viewCount": "388", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "likeCount": "5", "dislikeCount": "0"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1002/fee.2015", "q": "10.1002/fee.2015", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT15M12S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UCEfEi-IMiB87UsxY3765P6w", "publishedAt": "2020-06-16T14:20:54Z", "defaultAudioLanguage": "en-US", "description": "Tabloidization versus Credibility: Short Term Gain for Long Term Pain\nBrendan Spillane, Isla Hoe, Mike Brady, Vincent Wade, S\u00e9amus Lawless\n\nCHI '20: ACM CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems\nSession: Portrayals & social media\n\nAbstract\nPrint news agencies have been under pressure from falling sales and advertising revenue and increased competition. As the Internet became the dominant medium, news agencies invested heavily in their websites and apps, providing their news for free, rather than selling a print edition. Reducing the cost of production and removing access barriers such as geographic location had the potential to increase readership and advertising, covering costs and maintaining profits. Unfortunately, this business model has for the most part failed. Many higher quality news agencies are now implementing paywalls on their news websites to once again monetize their product. Others have begun to emulate the look and feel of tabloid news websites to increase readership and stickiness and advertising revenue. This study shows the negative impact of such visual tabloidization on initial impressions of credibility, which may have long term detrimental effects on the news agency.\n\nDOI:: https://doi.org/10.1145/3313831.3376388\nWEB:: https://chi2020.acm.org/\n\nRemote Presentations for the ACM CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems 2020.", "channelTitle": "ACM SIGCHI", "title": "Tabloidization versus Credibility: Short Term Gain for Long Term Pain"}, "id": "pPQnBDpx3Js", "statistics": {"viewCount": "21", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "likeCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1002/fee.2015", "q": "10.1002/fee.2015", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT6M37S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UCPQS5BOA_GLQKCc07ZCOjJg", "tags": ["incontinence exercises after prostate surgery", "Kegels after prostatectomy", "Kegels for men", "Prostatectomy incontinence", "prostatectomy exercises", "pelvic floor exercises prostatectomy", "physiotherapy", "health education", "bladder exercises men"], "publishedAt": "2020-06-11T14:00:20Z", "defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "description": "These  Kegel exercises can stop bladder leakage fast after prostate removal surgery. Pelvic Floor Physiotherapist Michelle guides you through Kegels for prostatectomy after catheter removal. Learn the best Kegels positions to start, the correct Kegel exercise technique and how many Kegels you need to do daily to overcome bladder leakage fast after prostatectomy surgery.\n\n#prostateexercises #prostatectomyincontinence\n\nTranscribe this video: http://www.youtube.com/timedtext_video?v=ldCPTP1hVtY&ref=share\n\nThis is general information for overcoming bladder incontinence after prostate removal surgery through pelvic floor muscle training. Please follow the guidance of your medical professional after your surgery and  consult with a pelvic floor physiotherapist for your post operative management.\n\nThis prostatectomy exercises video is an overview for initial pelvic floor training after surgery covering:\n*When and best positions to start pelvic floor training \n*How to do pelvic floor exercises for bladder control\n*How to test your exercises\n*How many exercises to do \n\n1. When to Start Exercises and Best Training Positions\nMost men start post operative pelvic floor training after their catheter has been removed and with their surgeon's approval. It's beneficial to start pelvic floor training before prostatectomy surgery.\n\nKegels positions:\n*Lying down \n*Semireclined \n*Standing upright \n\nHow to do Pelvic Floor Exercises for Prostatectomy Incontinence\nThe pelvic floor muscles trained for bladder control sit at the base of the penis (bulbospongiosis) and deeper inside around the urine tube (striated urethral sphincter). There are 2 parts to Kegels after prostatectomy. The correct technique involves shortening the penis (retracting) and contracting as if to stop the flow of urine.\n\n-Start by relaxing your breathing, your buttocks and your belly. Breathe normally and keep your upper belly relaxed \n-Relax your pelvic floor muscles to resting after each exercise\n\nTest Your Kegel Exercises\n\nTest whether you're doing your pelvic exercises correctly by:\n1. Stopping or slowing the flow of urine - only once a week as a test not an exercise\n2. Watching in the mirror to see your penis move slightly inwards towards your body\n\nHow Many Exercises to Start With\n*Start with 2-3 second exercises \n*Repeat these exercises gently 5-10 times \n*At first try to do this routine 2-3 times a day.\n\nTo Progress your Exercises\n\nOver the next 2-3 weeks progress your exercises by:\n*Holding each exercise up to 10 seconds, breathing normally and keeping your upper belly relaxed\n*Repeating these exercises gently up to 10 times in a row using correct Kegel technique\n\nTry to do this Kegels routine 3-6 times a day to improve bladder control after prostate surgery.\n\nReferences\n1. Hodges, P., Stafford, R., Hall, L., Neumann, P., Morrison, S., Frawley, H., \u2026 Cameron, A. (2019). Reconsideration of pelvic floor muscle training to prevent and treat incontinence after radical prostatectomy. Urologic Oncology. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.urolonc.2019.12.007\n\n2. Stafford RE, Ashton-Millar JA, Constantinou C, Couglin C, Lutton NJ, Hodges P. Pattern of activation of pelvic floor muscles in men differs with verbal instructions. Neuro Urod. 2015. https://doi.org/10.1002/nau. 22745\n\n3. Milios, J., Ackland, T., & Green, D. (2019). Pelvic floor muscle training in \nradical prostatectomy: A randomized controlled trial of the impacts on pelvic floor muscle function and urinary incontinence. The paper is here\nhttp://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/smj.4250171105/pdf:", "title": "SMJ Best Paper - Gabriel Szulanski (2004) - Internal stickiness (long version)", "publishedAt": "2015-01-29T17:50:59Z", "channelTitle": "Strategic Management Society"}, "id": "bv542tHkAX8", "statistics": {"viewCount": "458", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "likeCount": "8", "dislikeCount": "0"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1002/fee.2015", "q": "10.1002/fee.2015", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1M50S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UCr_TJLZTKe_fgMKJwZMiDmQ", "description": "Bees are a vital part of how our ecosystem functions. Without them, we would have tremendously less crops and our diets would lack micronutrients that are essential to our wellbeing (\u201cWhy do we need Bees?\u201d). When bees pollinate crops and flower plants, they help plants grow, breed more plants, and produce food by transferring pollen between plants (\u201cWhy do we need Bees?\u201d). Thus, our ecosystem heavily depends on bees to assist in the plant growing process. However, in recent decades, the bee population has been declining. One reason for their decline is the pesticides that cause many bee fatalities. Another reason is the diminishment of ideal areas for bee habitats, such as areas of natural vegetation that is frequently trimmed to make gardens appear nicer. One solution to promoting the existence and conservation of the bee population is urban, green spaces. These spaces are vital to bee survival because they act as preservation sites where vegetation and shrubbery grow naturally so bees can establish their habitats (Turo and Gardiner). The idea of urban green spaces promotes the flourishment and conservation of bees in urban areas that is necessary for our future. Because bees are so important to our ecosystems and to our well-being, it is crucial that we do everything we can to help preserve what is left of the bee population. \r\n\n\r\nWorks Cited\r\n\nCalhoun, Jeanette. \u201cDutchess as a bumble bee in her Halloween Costume- Ragdoll Cat.\u201d Pinterest, https://www.pinterest.com/pin/291326669617560019/?lp=true. \r\n\nTuro, Katherine J., and Mary M. The European Commission\u2019s landmark REACh regulation set a high standard, and regulatory agencies around the world are moving towards chemical regulatory reform. The resulting need to characterize thousands of chemicals with regard to their hazard, risk, and exposure potential poses an enormous task, and dozens of chemical assessment tools have been developed to aid assessors. An article in the April 2015 issue of IEAM identifies the most robust and comprehensive tools used in chemical assessment. Co-author Julie Panko discusses how she and her fellow authors critically evaluated dozens of chemical assessment tools, to help assessors select the right tool for the job. \n\n\n\nBio for Julie Panko\n\nMs. Panko is a Principal Health Scientist with the consulting firm ChemRisk.  She has 25 years of experience in conducting and managing a wide variety of environmental and occupational health risk assessments and is a certified industrial hygienist.  A large portion of her practice is dedicated to the evaluation of chemical risks from industrial, commercial, and consumer products.  Some of these have included product lines such as paints and coatings, adhesives, tires, arts and crafts, beauty care, and many industrial process chemicals. Since 2006, Julie has been the technical lead and project manager for a large sustainability initiative sponsored by the international tire industry to understand potential environmental health risks from the manufacturing and in-use portions of the tire life cycle.  Ms. Panko and her colleagues at ChemRisk are researching the use of chemical footprinting as a tool to evaluate chemical risks associated with a product throughout its lifecycle, and provide a transparent and scientific method for evaluating chemical substitutes.    \n\n\nADDITIONAL RESOURCES:\n\nGauthier, et al. "UCocUu8iWasfmkgkUzDKJUcA", "description": "Special Organized Session: Long-Term Care Financing and Markets\n\nChair: Sally Stearns (The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill)\n\nPresenters: Adelina Comas-Herrera (London School of Economics and Political Science); Naoki Ikegami (St Luke\u2019s International University); Marcello Morciano (University of Manchester)\n\nAs the 21st Century progresses, it is clear that the ageing of the population is a global phenomenon which affects not only high-income countries. It is also becoming clearer that the profile of the population who will be needing care and support through health and long-term care systems is changing rapidly, as the population living with multiple chronic conditions (including dementia) and dependency increases. The management of contaminated sediment is often expensive and time-consuming, involving millions of dollars over many years at a single site. However, an easier solution may be coming to a regulatory agency near you. Passive sampling methods offer several advantages over traditional remediation and monitoring techniques, and are the focus of this podcast episode. \n\nBio for Marc Greenberg\n\n\nDr Marc S Greenberg is the Deputy Branch Chief of the USEPA\u2019s the Environmental Response Team. His office supports various clean-up, emergency, and other response actions within the USEPA Superfund program. Marc\u2019s technical area of focus has been the assessment, remediation, and management of contaminated sediment sites. His research experience includes both human health and aquatic ecological toxicology. Marc has provided technical and policy advice in the fields of contaminated sediments and soils, toxicology, ecological risk assessment, and oil spill response. He has mentored and coached numerous technical specialists inside and outside the Agency. Dr Greenberg has served as a member of the EPA Contaminated Sediments Technical Advisory Group (CSTAG), Risk Assessment Forum Ecological Oversight Committee, Superfund Sediments Team, and EPA Headquarters Chair of the Agency\u2019s Ecological Risk Assessment Forum (ERAF). He has participated in the standardizing of sediment toxicity testing methods for the USEPA, has co-authored many EPA technical and guidance documents, and has contributed to the authorship of numerous peer-reviewed papers and book chapters. He is an active member of the Society for Environmental Toxicology and Chemistry (SETAC), and he served on its North America Board of Directors (2007-2010) and Editorial Board for the SETAC journals (2010-2012). He obtained a BA in Zoology (1990) and a MS in Aquatic Toxicology (1993) from Miami University, and a PhD in Biomedical Sciences from Wright State University (2002). \n\n\nADDITIONAL RESOURCES:\n\nParkerton and Maruya, Passive sampling in contaminated sediment assessment: Building consensus to improve decision making , IEAM 10#2:163\u2013166.\nhttp://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/ieam.1488/abstract\n\nLydy et al., Passive sampling methods for contaminated sediments: State of the science for organic contaminants, IEAM 10#2:167\u2013178.\nhttp://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/ieam.1503/abstract\n\nPeijnenburg et al., Passive sampling methods for contaminated sediments: State of the science for metals, IEAM 10#2:179\u2013196.\nhttp://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/ieam.1502/abstract\n\nMayer et al., Passive sampling methods for contaminated sediments: Scientific rationale supporting use of freely dissolved concentrations, IEAM 10#2:197\u2013209.\nhttp://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/ieam.1508/abstract\n\nGhosh et al., Passive sampling methods for contaminated sediments: Practical guidance for selection, calibration, and implementation, IEAM 10#2:210\u2013223.\nhttp://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/ieam.1507/abstract\n\nGreenberg et al., Passive sampling methods for contaminated sediments: Risk assessment and management, IEAM 10#2:224-236. \nhttp://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/ieam.1511/abstract", "channelTitle": "Wiley", "title": "IEAM Podcast 15:Sedimentary, my dear Watson. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, 2017 (Open Access)\n(http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/14651858.CD011244.pub2/full)", "channelTitle": "TARG Bristol", "title": "Plain packaging for tobacco"}, "id": "dYpd1-Eo-l4", "statistics": {"viewCount": "705", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "likeCount": "7", "dislikeCount": "1"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1002/fee.2015", "q": "10.1002/fee.2015", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT4M10S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UCqeIRvS2Z_Q0p70ARvphdLA", "publishedAt": "2016-09-14T06:41:53Z", "defaultAudioLanguage": "en-US", "description": "Strategic Management Journal article by Short, Toffel and Hugill\nhttp://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/smj.2417/full\nFirms seeking to avoid reputational spillovers that can arise from dangerous, illegal, and unethical behavior at supply chain factories are increasingly relying on private social auditors to provide strategic information about suppliers' conduct. But little is known about what influences auditors' ability to identify and report problems. Our analysis of nearly 17,000 supplier audits reveals that auditors report fewer violations when individual auditors have audited the factory before, when audit teams are less experienced or less trained, when audit teams are all male, and when audits are paid for by the audited supplier. This first comprehensive and systematic analysis of supply chain monitoring identifies previously overlooked transaction costs and suggests strategies to develop governance structures to mitigate reputational risks by reducing information asymmetries in supply chains.", "channelTitle": "Strategic Management Society", "title": "Monitoring Global Supply Chains"}, "id": "OLq4GixoVZ8", "statistics": {"viewCount": "755", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "2", "likeCount": "3", "dislikeCount": "0"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1002/fee.2015", "q": "10.1002/fee.2015", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT43M45S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UCSccnE9-Y9PfJC2thw-vgtg", "tags": ["podcast", "italiano", "italia", "scienza", "editoria", "editori", "costi", "prezzo", "pubblicazione", "pubblicazioni", "scientifico", "scientifica", "scientifiche", "Elsevier", "Nature", "Science", "Cell", "the", "Lancet", "Springer", "Wiley", "Blackwell", "Sci-hub", "Elbakyan", "aaron", "swartz", "alexandra", "New", "England", "journal", "medicine", "scandalo"], "publishedAt": "2020-06-30T10:00:14Z", "defaultAudioLanguage": "it", "description": "I grandi editori scientifici impongono prezzi, si rifiutano di ritrarre pubblicazioni e tradiscono le stesse regole di peer-review che hanno imposto? of human belief revision\u2014 desirability bias and confirmation bias.\nConfirmation bias is the tendency to search for, interpret, favour, and recall information in a way that confirms one's preexisting beliefs or hypotheses while desirability bias is a bias toward a belief we want to be true and contends that individuals assign greater weight to information that is desirable versus Here you can get a lot of information such as the admission, testimony, and also the study program.", "title": "Online Info Session Doctor of Science in Management 4 April 2020", "publishedAt": "2020-04-04T05:30:11Z", "channelTitle": "SBM ITB"}, "id": "Dq7v8WtW7s0", "statistics": {"viewCount": "860", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "1", "likeCount": "18", "dislikeCount": "0"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1002/fee.2015", "q": "10.1002/fee.2015", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1H4M20S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UCf5RZWvpGU0RTBhXBMrc0jw", "tags": ["Water-Energy-Food Nexus", "membranes", "clean water", "water treatment", "distillation", "nanomaterials"], "publishedAt": "2020-06-10T09:23:08Z", "defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "description": "2017.03.06\nDavid M. Warsinger, Mechanical Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA \n\nClimate change, degrading water resources, and economic and population growth are increasing the need for new science and technologies at the Water-Energy-Food Nexus. In enabling new and improved technologies to tackle these issues, new nanomaterials designed with systems-level thermodynamics is essential to improve efficiency, allow for new power sources, and enable applications to agriculture. Following this approach, thermodynamic design of water treatment membrane technologies such as reverse osmosis (RO) and membrane distillation (MD) leads to innovations with superhydrophobic nanostructured surfaces for enhanced heat transfer, time-varying \u201cbatch\u201d cycles, new system configurations, and optimal use of waste heat can more than double system efficiencies. Furthermore, optimization of heat and mass transfer and chemical thermodynamics in these technologies allows for nanofabricated membranes with superior flux and fouling resistance, including graphene oxide multilayer membranes. These approaches not only yield significant improvements in water treatment and associated energy use, but also in providing water and energy needs for food applications, such as pumping energy for agricultural ground water, or using phase-change thermal storage to enable refrigeration of food despite intermittent power in the developing world.\n\nAvailable on nanoHUB.org https://nanohub.org/resources/26190\n\nReferences:\n\u2022 World Economic Forum, Geneva, Switzerland, \"Global risks 2015 10th edition,\" 2015.\n\u2022 D. M. Warsinger, K. H. Mistry, K. G. Nayar, H. W. Chung, and J. H. Lienhard V, \"Entropy generation of desalination powered by variable temperature waste heat,\" Entropy, vol. 17, pp. 7530-7566, 2015. https://doi.org/10.3390/e17117530\n\u2022 D. M. Warsinger, J. Swaminathan, and J. H. The reason why when you pick up a bag of Doritos you finish it and could still eat more, the reason why quarantine weight gain is going to be likely because our brain is wired to make us put on weight with specific cravings. Presenter Noah Fahlgren, one of the creators of Plant Computer Vision (PlantCV), gives an overview of how PlantCV is built, what research can be done with PlantCV, and how users can apply it to their own projects. He explains some of the built-in tools that include traditional image analysis and machine learning methods, and how these can be combined with other image analysis tools from the Python community. Noah then demonstrates how to build your own image analysis workflows on your laptop, on your own servers, or on CyVerse using VICE. If you've ever wanted to do image-based plant (or other organisms!) phenotyping, this webinar will show you that image-based analysis in your research is achievable and that you do not need an expensive system for imaging to get started now!\n\nWebinar materials, including interactive slides, are available here: https://cyverse.org/webinar-plantcv-image-analysis-toolkit-for-building-plant-phenotyping-workflows\n\nCyVerse provides powerful infrastructure for computational research involving large datasets and complex analyses. The program built on the success and learnings of the J2SI Pilot (2009-12), which supported 40 people in the St Kilda area.\n\nJ2SI Phase Three is currently underway and incorporates learnings from the delivery of Phase Two as part of SHM\u2019s practice of continuous improvement. Phase Three is funded by a Social Impact Investment with the Victorian Government to support 180 people in Melbourne.\n\nJ2SI is an evidence-based model, with both the Pilot and Phase Two independently evaluated. Phase Two has been evaluated by a team of researchers from Swinburne University of Technology and the Centre for Social Impact at The University of Western Australia.\n\nParticipants were randomly assigned to two groups, with one group receiving support through J2SI and the other continuing to receive support as usual.\n\nOutcomes for the two groups are presented in the evaluation reports, which were launched during this impact2020 webinar. To download the reports visit:\n\n-  https://bit.ly/J2SI_quantitative_report_2020 \n-  https://bit.ly/J2SI_qualitative_report_2020\n\nThe findings will contribute to the continuous improvement of J2SI and SHM\u2019s ambition to scale J2SI nationally through the J2SI Evaluation and Learning Centre (ELC). In partnership with service providers, the ELC will enable J2SI to support more people out of homelessness across Australia.\n\nListen to this webinar for an in-depth analysis of the highly successful J2SI program, with:\n\n- Cathy Humphrey, CEO, Sacred Heart Mission\n- Professor Paul Flatau, Director, Centre for Social Impact, The University of Western Australia\n- Associate Professor Monica Thielking, Chair, Department of Psychological Sciences, Swinburne University\n- Fred, a former Journey to Social Inclusion participant\n\nAbout impact2020:\n\nThese are unprecedented times and the upheaval to our society will require an extraordinary response from our leaders, our thinkers and our do-ers.\n\nimpact2020 - presented by the Centre for Social Impact - offered free daily webinars with our educators, researchers and thought leaders in daily webinars over six weeks during April, May and June 2020. We covered the breadth and complexity of social impact and we brought our diverse Australian for-purpose sector together.\n\nYou can watch the 35 webinar recordings in our impact2020 YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLsrOHY-8USXvCtLF0FfDAmGXWIJKjlOtH \n\nAs the first impact2020 webinar series was so successful CSI is producing monthly webinars in partnership with our network from June 2020. [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1H9M53S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UClyPB1mCHOP0zdexxaN7HUQ", "tags": ["Water", "Youth", "Network", "IWRM", "Economics", "Policy", "Climate", "Change", "Cycle", "Integrated Water Resources Management", "webinar"], "publishedAt": "2020-07-08T07:41:22Z", "defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "description": "The Connection of IWRM, the Terrestrial Water Cycle and Climate Change Mitigation: The role that economics and economic policies can play\n\nEconomics is a discipline that helps to manage scarcity issues that people usually connect to water only if the lack of drinking water or irrigation water is at stake. In case of a broader view, what IWRM stands for is the integrated approach that should consider ecosystem services along similar lines because when an IWRM plan decides on the allocation of water in the landscape, it inadvertently also decides on the redistribution of ecosystem services that are derived at that location. These IWR management decisions also have an impact on how regulatory ecosystems services (with mostly public interests) and provisioning ecosystem services (with more individual interest at stake) can be harnessed. Our economic minded approach on the terrestrial water cycle will help to structure all these issues of local water uses and mitigation within one frame.\n\nSPEAKERS: G\u00e1bor Ungv\u00e1ri, Senior Water Economist, REKK.AQUA | Andras Kis - Explosives and war materials kill animals, and valuable wildlife products like ivory finance militias. However, the most devastating effects of conflict on wildlife are driven by societal upheaval. War triggers a domino effect of institutional, economic, and social changes that can wreak havoc on the environment. \n\nDuring wartime, law enforcement breaks down, food security is compromised, and livelihoods are upended. This upheaval can drive the exploitation of wildlife and other natural resources. In rare cases, war can be beneficial to wildlife\u2014as people flee militarized regions, they leave behind wildlife \u201crefuges.\u201d But these positive outcomes are few and far between, and are often accompanied by negative outcomes in another place or time.\n\nIn a recent publication in Frontiers in Ecology and the Environment, we review case studies from around the world to understand the links between war and wildlife. How, exactly, does war affect animal habitats and populations? For a given conflict, understanding these processes is a critical first step towards conservation during and after wartime. \n\nhttp://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/fee.1433/full\n\n\n----\nPHOTO CREDITS\nJ. Dr Wole Akosile - Adjunct Senior Lecturer at the University of Queensland and Griffith University\n\nThe rates of SUDS in patients with non-substance use psychiatric diagnosis is very high. There is a complex interaction between both disorders. The aetiological principles behind both disorders are likely similar and include social, environmental, psychological, genetic and epigenetic factors. Having these disorders come at a great personal cost to the individual, their families and broader society. This presentation will explore factors contributing to the development of both disorders beginning with early childhood environment, attachment and parenting styles. It will also explore the role of culture and society in perpetuating or curtailing these disorders and the cost and toll on our society and family. "snippet": {"channelId": "UC6jTjb1J_TT5jvHNLXGHSvQ", "publishedAt": "2019-07-19T21:48:52Z", "defaultAudioLanguage": "es-419", "description": "", "channelTitle": "Concytec Per\u00fa", "title": "#EnVivo "UCOyJp_VIIUltgLa3KwqGpJg", "tags": ["TSPCCM", "COPD passport", "SDM", "shared-decision making", "self-management", "long-term care system", "\u53f0\u7063\u80f8\u8154\u91ab\u5b78\u6703", "\u80ba\u963b\u585e"], "publishedAt": "2019-12-04T08:00:09Z", "defaultAudioLanguage": "zh-TW", "description": "This short video is used for demonstration of my recent works on the design of COPD
