Meeting: my two posters for presentation", "defaultLanguage": "zh-TW"}, "id": "eKqYcT-JkiU", "statistics": {"viewCount": "22", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "likeCount": "1", "dislikeCount": "0"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1002/fee.2015", "q": "10.1002/fee.2015", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT10M1S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UCdETpxXdItGhajxNuzvtGpA", "description": "Oil spills, defined as the leakage of petroleum onto the surface of large bodies of water, are a major global issue. There are a multitude of causes that contribute to the severity of this problem, including the drilling of petroleum carried out in or near the sea, the leakage of fuel from water sports or vehicles, leakage of products containing petroleum on land into the ocean, and equipment faults of oil tankers. Combined with the natural seepage from the ocean, these sources add to the world\u2019s waterways at a rate of 3.5 to 6 million metric tons a year. \n       Oceanic oil spills grew to pose a major environmental threat in the 1960s due to heightened petroleum exploration and production on continental shelves as well as the use of supertankers. As a result, scientists have attempted to search for a method that can effectively clean the spill and help to alleviate the damage. Although many methods have failed, in recent decades, scientists have spent much time altering the structure of carbon nanotubes, which consist of atom-thick sheets of carbon rolled into cylinders. They originally caught the attention of scientists due to their high strength, conductivity, as well as their lightweight structure. However, it has been discovered that by adding boron to the hexagonal carbon lattice of atoms, an element that has a different number of valence electrons, the result is the formation of \u201celbow\u201d junctions that facilitate the growth of the nanotubes into a 3-D network. By altering the structure of the carbon nanotube in this way, it begins to grow into a woven sponge-like material that is three-dimensionally strong and efficient at absorbing oil because it attracts oil while repelling water. This material also has magnetic properties, which allows for easy control or removal externally during the cleanup of oil spills. For these reasons along with other properties of the material, carbon nanotubes have acquired the potential to be used as one of the primary processes for cleaning up oil spills. \n\nReferences:\nhttp://www.nature.com/srep/2012/120413/srep00363/full/srep00363.html?WT.ec_id=SREP-639-20120501 \nhttp://www.dailytech.com/BoronCarbon+Nanosponges+Used+to+Absorb+Oil+from+Water+/article24481.htm \nhttp://www.nature.com/srep/2012/120413/srep00363/full/srep00363.html?iframe=true&width=900&height=450 \nhttp://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/adma.200902986/full \nhttp://www.gizmag.com/carbon-nanotube-sponges/30511/ \ntp://www.iop.org/news/14/jan/page_62331.html \nhttp://www.understandingnano.com/nanotubes-carbon-properties.html  \nhttp://mechanosynthesis.mit.edu/journals/076_devolder_13_sciencereview.pdf\nhttp://www.livescience.com/9885-faq-science-history-oil-spills.html \n http://www.epa.gov/osweroe1/content/learning/response.htm \nhttp://www.afsc.noaa.gov/Quarterly/jas2001/feature_jas01.htm  http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/how-long-will-oil-spill-last/ \nSources: Ando, T. Further, we will be addressing the most common, and some of the less common, health claims that are lobbied against the consumption of meat by various interest groups.\n\nAlso one thing that I left unmentioned in the video but feel like I should mention upon uploading this video: Just because meat consumption is a natural product of human evolution, doesn't mean you should ignore your vegetables. Remember to eat your vegetables too.\n\nOne of the cats did their absolute best to make even more obvious my jump cuts and overall poor editing skills.\n_________________________________________________________________\nSources used:\nhttps://cancerresearch.org/immunotherapy/stories/scientists/oliver-m-pearce,-ph-d\n\nhttps://www.americanscientist.org/article/meat-eating-among-the-earliest-humans\n\nhttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australopithecus\n\nhttps://www.nationalgeographic.com/foodfeatures/evolution-of-diet/\n\nhttps://www.ucdmc.ucdavis.edu/publish/news/newsroom/11551\n\nhttp://www.pnas.org/content/112/2/542\n\nhttps://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/bpb/37/5/37_b13-00967/_html/-char/en\n\nhttps://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1002/art.20761\n\nhttp://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0038123\n\nhttps://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa035700#t=articleTop\n\nhttps://www.livestrong.com/article/207342-high-uric-acid-foods-list/\n\nhttps://www.hsph.harvard.edu/news/press-releases/processed-meats-unprocessed-heart-disease-diabetes/\n\nhttps://www.health.harvard.edu/blog/new-study-links-l-carnitine-in-red-meat-to-heart-disease-201304176083\n\nhttps://www.quora.com/What-are-chimpanzee-digestive-systems-like-compared-to-humans\u2019\n\nhttps://www.niddk.nih.gov/health-information/digestive-diseases/digestive-system-how-it-works\n\nhttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maya_cuisine\n_________________________________________________________________\n\nMusic used: \"DM2012\" by Adragante. License: https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode\n\nNeither I, nor the content in this video, in any capacity, is endorsed by the artist.", "channelTitle": "M\u0394C R\u03b8SS", "title": "The Evolution of the Human Diet, and other similar topics."}, "id": "d6zHU4Bt6V0", "statistics": {"viewCount": "39", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "likeCount": "4", "dislikeCount": "0"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1002/fee.2015", "q": "10.1002/fee.2015", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT3M15S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UClydU5bsfQTzebnMMZ4CqUw", "tags": ["science", "science communication", "The Young Turks", "dairy", "healthy bones", "US Government", "Guidelines", "servings", "calcium", "milk", "cheese", "corruption", "marketing", "advertising", "milk industry", "milk lobby", "vitamins", "minerals", "nutrient", "hip fractures", "milk consumption", "dairy industry", "lobbying", "dietary guidelines", "eggs", "greens", "government", "yogurt", "lobby", "industry", "health", "nutrition", "diet", "bones", "corrupt", "cancer", "cows", "cattle", "farms", "farmers", "humane", "inhumane"], "publishedAt": "2017-02-09T17:53:13Z", "defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "description": "So, we grow up hearing we needs three servings of dairy per day for good strong healthy bones. That\u2019s the official US Government guidelines - 3 serves of dairy every day and you\u2019ll get all the calcium your body needs. \n\nBut where does that number really come from? And is it possible that the U.S. Government\u2019s dietary guidelines are\u2026 corrupt?\n\n[sciq swoosh]\n\nAs it turns out, milk is one of the last things we need. This really frustrates me  because coming from the world of marketing and advertising. I used to work for the milk industry and i know how much money they pay to lobby the government. So ,if you ever suspected the government is corrupt i can verify that.\n\nHere\u2019s something to remember for any food you eat for their vitamins and minerals: eating a food rich in a nutrient doesn\u2019t matter unless that nutrient is actually absorbed by your body . I could drink liquid iron all day long: if it doesn\u2019t get absorbed into by body it won\u2019t do a thing for my health, except cause a lot of permanent damage to my mouth or, more likely, kill me very quickly - Viserys Targaryen style.\n\nPoint is, milk is very rich in calcium but that doesn\u2019t mean it helps strengthen our bones. In fact, milk may actually lower our \u201cbone mineral density\u201d which may explain why there\u2019s more hip fractures in the elderly living in the western world where milk consumption is high, compared to Eastern asian cultures that don\u2019t drink much milk. So much for milk helping bones get strong! \n\nNow, there is even an hypothesis that milk draws calcium out of the bones. What the hell, milk? I trusted you with my calcium! Here\u2019s what they think is going on: milk is acidic, it is about 6.5 on the ph scale. Acid freaks the body out and it scrambles to neutralize the acidic so it doesn\u2019t get all the way to the kidneys, and to do that it ends up sacrificing calcium from bones. \n\nNow, your body does need calcium. BUT we don\u2019t have to get our calcium from dairy. We can get our calcium needs from:leafy greens, tofu, broccoli, snap peas, almonds, canned fish with bones, leeks, green onions, endive, fennel, cabbage, butternut squash, artichokes, brussel sprouts, sweet potato, parsnips, lima beans, carrots, and turnips). So why do the U.S. guidelines emphasize dairy?\n\nWell, the answer is - money. The US govt is heavily influenced by the dairy industry. And as i said I used to work for the dairy industry at my previous PR agency back in 2014. Remember the \u201cGot Milk?\u201d campaign - yeah I helped promote that. That was back before I started ScIQ, and I'm doing ScIQ as kind of a penance for all the bad things Ive done as a PR agent.  Anyway, the dairy industry know damn well you don\u2019t *need* all that milk, but all that lobbying got the US Government to endorse milk in their official guidelines. Years later, we all kind of accept that milk is essential, even though it\u2019s not! \n\nSo let\u2019s be clear here \u2013 the U.S. dietary guidelines, which gives meat and dairy a big chunk of the food plate \u2013 are NOT the unbiased recommendation of scientists. That is literally a pyramid scheme where get you to buy more eggs, milk, cheese and yogurt. If you want find out more about Big Dairy and the effects they have on the government, check out the links in the description. \n\nWhat do you guys think I know the dairy Industry is just one of the many sources of government lobbying. Is there a particular industry sector or group that you think is lobbying the government you would like us to explore. Let us know in the comments below. \n\nHI everyone! I'm Jayde Lovell, resident science nerd at the Young Turks Network. (The Milk Industrial Complex)", "defaultLanguage": "en"}, "id": "6mkEvirnWyc", "statistics": {"viewCount": "4055", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "56", "likeCount": "192", "dislikeCount": "8"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1002/fee.2015", "q": "10.1002/fee.2015", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1H20M25S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UC8PJqHlMhT4p69EzsE2Jz2w", "description": "Los materiales termoel\u00e9ctricos (TE) son ampliamente conocidos por su capacidad de convertir la energ\u00eda t\u00e9rmica en energ\u00eda el\u00e9ctrica y viceversa. La eficiencia termoel\u00e9ctrica est\u00e1 relacionada con la figura de m\u00e9rito zT la cual correlaciona la dependencia entre el coeficiente Sebeeck, la conductividad el\u00e9ctrica y la conductividad t\u00e9rmica. Una de las principales rutas abordadas en el incremento de esta eficiencia TE es precisamente la reducci\u00f3n en la conductividad t\u00e9rmica sin disminuir el coeficiente Sebeeck o la conductividad el\u00e9ctrica. En esta l\u00ednea de investigaci\u00f3n, presentamos un novedoso proceso de fabricaci\u00f3n de nanoestructuras (tanto en pel\u00edcula delgada como nano-mallas) de Silicio-Germanio (Si0.8Ge0.2) a trav\u00e9s de pulverizaci\u00f3n cat\u00f3dica a bajas temperaturas de sustrato. Esta nueva aproximaci\u00f3n, nos permite controlar el tama\u00f1o de poro, espesor y tiempo de dep\u00f3sito en un solo paso, brindando la posibilidad de recubrir grandes \u00e1reas sin necesidad de recurrir a procesos litogr\u00e1ficos o tratamientos t\u00e9rmicos adicionales. As\u00ed mismo, mediante la fabricaci\u00f3n de estas nano-mallas, hemos reducido la conductividad t\u00e9rmica a valores r\u00e9cord, similares a los reportados en la literatura para nano-hilos [1-3].\n\nEn lo que respecta a aplicaciones de materiales TE en temperaturas cercanas al ambiente, recientes investigaciones de seleniuros en volumen han reportado altos valores de eficiencia termoel\u00e9ctrica, debido a sus bajos valores de conductividad t\u00e9rmica y altos valores de coeficiente Sebeeck y conductividad el\u00e9ctrica. Esto se debe fundamentalmente a su inusual comportamiento como semiconductor superi\u00f3nico, lo que ha dado lugar a un nuevo concepto en el campo conocido como \u2018Phonon-liquid electron-crystal - PLEC\u2019. En este sentido, recientemente hemos reportado un significativo avance en la obtenci\u00f3n de nanoestructuras en forma de pel\u00edcula delgada de seleniuro de cobre (Cu2-xSe) [4] y de seleniuro de plata (Ag2Se) \u200b\u200bFigura 1 [5] con alta eficiencia termoel\u00e9ctrica a temperaturas cercanas a la ambiental. Este mejoramiento en la eficiencia TE es obtenido gracias al desarrollo de una nueva t\u00e9cnica de crecimiento la cual hemos llamado pulse controlled reactive magnetron sputtering [4-5]. Esta t\u00e9cnica permite un fino control de la estequiometria, orientaci\u00f3n cristalogr\u00e1fica y eficiencia termoel\u00e9ctrica a bajas temperaturas de sustrato siendo compatible con la fabricaci\u00f3n de pel\u00edculas delgadas sobre sustratos org\u00e1nicos y/o flexibles. Esta nueva adaptaci\u00f3n tecnol\u00f3gica despliega un abanico de nuevas oportunidad y aplicaciones que antes no eran posible mediante la sinterizaci\u00f3n en volumen (en forma de pellets) de estos materiales como se ha venido realizando.\n\n\u200b\u200b\n\u200b\n\u200b\u200b\u200b\u200b\u200bFigura 1. En (a) la figura de m\u00e9rito a traves de los valores de zT obtenidos a temperatura ambiente para diferentes estequiometr\u00edas de Ag / Se. Reportamos con nuestras pel\u00edculas delgadas, valores record con las m\u00e1s altas eficiencia termoelectrica para este material. Esto es debido a la dr\u00e1stica reducci\u00f3n de la conductividad t\u00e9rmica. En (b) se muestra la dependencia de los diferentes valores de zT para Ag2Se a temperatura ambiente en funci\u00f3n de la concentraci\u00f3n de portadores de carga.\u200b\n\n\u200b\u200bReferencias\n\n[1] J.A P\u00e9rez-Taborda et.al, Silicon-Germanium (SiGe) Nanostructures for Thermoelectric Devices: Recent Advances and New Approaches to High Thermoelectric Efficiency, In book, Publisher: InTechOpen, 2017.\n[2] J.A P\u00e9rez-Taborda et.al, Ultra-low thermal conductivities in large-area Si-Ge nanomeshes for thermoelectric applications in Scientific Reports 6:32778, 2016.\n[3] J.A P\u00e9rez-Taborda et.al, Low thermal conductivity and improved thermoelectric performance of nanocrystalline silicon germanium films by sputtering in Nanotechnology 27(17):175401, 2016.\n[4] J.A P\u00e9rez-Taborda et.al, Pulsed Hybrid Reactive Magnetron Sputtering for High zT Cu2Se Thermoelectric Films, Advanced Materials Technologies, 201700012, 2017.\n[5] J. A. Perez-Taborda, O. Caballero-Calero, L. Vera-Londono, F. Briones, M. Martin-Gonzalez, Adv. Energy Mater. 2017, 1702024. https://doi.org/10.1002/aenm.201702024.\n\nDr. Jaime Andr\u00e9s P\u00e9rez Taborda: He received the Engineering Physics degree (Hons.) from the Technological University of Pereira, Colombia, in 2011, and the master's degree in Synchrotron Radiation and Particle Accelerators from the Universitat Aut\u00f2noma de Barcelona in 2013, as well as his Ph.D (Cum laude) from the Institute of Microelectronics of Madrid, Complutense University of Madrid, and Higher Council of Scientific Research CSIC, Spain. He has published research articles and book chapters on various subjects including piezoelectric nanostructures for acoustic wave sensors, nanoengineering new thermoelectric materials with high efficiencies obtained by physical methods, such as sputtering and pulsed laser deposition. In addition, he is also a co-founder and President of the Colombian Society of Physics Engineering.", "title": "Nanoestructuras termoel\u00e9ctricas de Alta eficiencia.  27 - Feb - 2018", Ask any questions in the comment section, related to this topic.", "channelTitle": "Pharmacist and Drugs", "title": "How to write an outstanding research article? | Dr Abhimanyu Thakur"}, "id": "YnJc6_OvOcA", "statistics": {"viewCount": "169", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "10", "likeCount": "32", "dislikeCount": "0"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1002/fee.2015", "q": "10.1002/fee.2015", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT58M46S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UC6Ce1JR4Qf4egQAqtxiwJrA", "tags": ["AAG", "American Association of Geographers"], "publishedAt": "2018-05-15T20:04:52Z", "defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "description": "In his address, \"Climate, Capital, Conflict \u2013 Geographies of Failure or Success in the 21st Century,\" AAG Past President Glen MacDonald asks the question: will people and planet succeed in meeting the challenges posed by the 21st century or will environmental and socioeconomic pressures, produce catastrophic failure? The address explores the mounting and often geographically conflated stresses of accelerating climate change, increasing economic disparities and associated conflicts - both in the sense of armed struggles, and in the sense of competing ideals regarding political and socioeconomic systems, valuation of the environment, and basic morality. The answer is elusive, but these challenges represent issues that geographers have long engaged with and must now confront with particular urgency. During the plenary session, MacDonald also presented the 2018 AAG Presidential Achievement Award to Susan Cutter and Billie L. Recorded on May 8th, 2019.\n\nApproximately a third of patients with major depressive disorder do not respond to treatment, with only half achieving remission. This results in high morbidity and makes MDD one of the leading causes of disability in the world per the World Health Organization. Early intervention, intensive and multimodal treatment are key to improving outcomes in this patient population. Challenges inherent to treatment include polymorphism in the presentation, multifactorial etiology and complex pathophysiology. In this presentation, we will review current evidence for approaching patients with difficult to treat presentations using psychotherapy, psychopharmacology, neurotherapeutics and complementary-alternative medicine. O uso de materiais de celulose possibilita o desenvolvimento de materiais de baixo custo para a realiza\u00e7\u00e3o de diagn\u00f3stico, e os desafios relacionados com o desenvolvimento desses dispositivos s\u00e3o apresentados pelo Prod. Dr. Arben Merko\u00e7i.\n\nResumo da Palestra pelo apresentador :\n\nAn efficient detection of pathogens is strongly related to biosensors. Unfortunately, the cost of biosensors and the lack of equipped centers and trained people are probably the hardest obstacles to the diffusion and use of these devices in pandemics situation as the one we are already living. Biosensors field is progressing rapidly and the demand for cost efficient platforms is the key factor for their success. Physical, chemical and mechanical properties of cellulose in both micro and nanofiberbased networks combined with their abundance in nature or easy to prepare and control procedures are making these materials of great interest while looking for cost-efficient and green alternatives for device production technologies. Both paper and nanopaper-based biosensors are emerging as a new class of devices with the objective to fulfil the \u201cWorld Health Organization\u201d requisites to be ASSURED: affordable, sensitive, specific, user-friendly, rapid and robust, equipment free and deliverable to endusers. How to design simple paper-based biosensor architectures? How to tune their analytical performance upon demand? How one can \u2018marriage\u2019 nanomaterials such as metallic nanoparticles, quantum dots and even graphene with paper and what is the benefit? How we can make these devices more robust, sensitive and with multiplexing capabilities? Can we bring these low cost and efficient devices to places with low resources, extreme conditions or even at our homes? Which are the perspectives to link these simple platforms and detection technologies with mobile phone communication? I will try to give responses to these questions through various interesting applications we have been developing so far for the detection of various biomarkers related to pathogens.\n\nEssa apresenta\u00e7\u00e3o \u00e9 parte do ciclo de palestras virtuais Webinars Covid-19. May 19, 2020: Methods for incorporating equity into economic evaluation", "publishedAt": "2020-05-20T14:39:59Z", "channelTitle": "iHEA Staff"}, "id": "YUwuiLEP5ew", "statistics": {"viewCount": "288", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "likeCount": "3", "dislikeCount": "0"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1002/fee.2015", "q": "10.1002/fee.2015", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1H3M16S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UCs7Ms1YLL1mZENCYUBu2u5A", "tags": ["Fusion", "Science", "fusion machine", "Tokamak", "Stellarator", "plasma", "physics", "engineering", "European Master", "student"], "publishedAt": "2020-05-20T07:33:58Z", "defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "description": "Presenter: Alexis Rustam Devitre, PhD candidate at Ghent University, Belgium.\n\n\ud83d\udcac Contact us directly on https://www.m.me/fusioneptalks\n or use the comments to ask questions!\n\nDate: May 11th, 2020\n\nSynopsis: The plasma facing surfaces of Tokamaks and Stellarators can be heat-treated (baked) or bombarded with energetic particles (discharge cleanings, refer FusionEPtalks #15 optimize their effect of fusion plasma. Alternatively, these surfaces can be coated with chemically active materials like Boron (B). These \"getters films\" retain impurities and cold fuel particles, whereby reducing the power losses and easing access to the high-performance regimes of interest. Lithium (Li) offers addition a broad range of in-vessel applications e.g. liquid targets, vapor-box divertor or edge-localized mode pacing. Enhanced confinement times, high-pressure pedestals and smoothed temperature gradients have also been observed under extensive Li coverage. In TJ-II, the deposition of a Boron film before lithiation was found to extend the lifetime of the very reactive Li film. During his Master thesis, the speaker explored the effect of this substrate and noticed a resilience to molecular oxidation, a consistent D retention and a large recovery of the gettering properties following a helium discharge treatment. In this talk, the speaker will review the benefits of Li wall-conditioning and discuss the synergies observed with a B (C) substrate.\n\n\n\ud83c\udf0d Fusion-EP Talks is a student-led seminar of the European Master In Fusion Science and Engineering program - \ud83d\udcda join our international degree @ http://www.em-master-fusion.org\n\n\n\ud83d\udd57 COMING UP NEXT on May 28th at 18:00 (CET): Vignesh Gopakumar will introduce the neural network solvers for partial differential equations. (Scientific machine learning engineer at the UK Atomic Energy Agency and alumni of the European Master in Fusion Science and Engineering Physics).\n\nLinks to the references:\nFusionEP talks #5: Effect of fast ion losses on the plasma facing components of W7X:\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d1VMZuo9pHo&t=55s\nFusion-EP Talks #15: Keep your Fusion Machine Clean!:\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xh0Sj4sJy-A&t=907s\nTabar\u00e9s, Contrib. Academic journals serve as permanent and transparent forums for the presentation, scrutiny, and discussion of research. They are usually peer-reviewed or refereed. Content typically takes the form of articles presenting original research, review articles, and book reviews. The purpose of an academic journal, according to Henry Oldenburg (the first editor of Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society), is to give researchers a venue to \"impart their knowledge to one another, and contribute what they can to the Grand design of improving natural knowledge, and perfecting all Philosophical Arts, and Sciences.\"The term academic journal applies to scholarly publications in all fields; this article discusses the aspects common to all academic field journals. Scientific journals and journals of the quantitative social sciences vary in form and function from journals of the humanities and qualitative social sciences; their specific aspects are separately discussed.\nThe first academic journal was Journal des s\u00e7avans (January 1665), followed soon after by Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society (March 1665), and M\u00e9moires de l'Acad\u00e9mie des Sciences (1666). When buyers and sellers have access to different information, traders with better private information about the quality of a product will selectively participate in trades which benefits them the most. A textbook example is Akerlof's market for lemons.\nBuyers sometimes have better information about how much benefit they can extract from a service in which case the \"bad\" customers are more likely to apply for the service. For example, an all-you-can-eat buffet restaurant which sets one price for all customers risks being adversely selected against by high appetite customers. Another example is in offering health insurance, the types of customers most likely to apply are those who are most prone to accidents.\n\n\nThis video is targeted to blind users.\n\nAttribution:\nArticle text available under CC-BY-SA\nCreative Commons image source in video", "title": "Adverse selection", "publishedAt": "2015-10-14T18:44:56Z", "channelTitle": "Audiopedia"}, "id": "pqV00tu0iD8", "statistics": {"viewCount": "1020", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "likeCount": "3", "dislikeCount": "0"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1002/fee.2015", "q": "10.1002/fee.2015", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT13M29S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UCV63FScHnShoobfaENC8R_Q", "description": "The framing effect is an example of cognitive bias, in which people react to a particular choice in different ways depending on how it is presented; e.g. as a loss or as a gain. People tend to avoid risk when a positive frame is presented but seek risks when a negative frame is presented. Gain and loss are defined in the scenario as descriptions of outcomes.\nProspect theory shows that a loss is more significant than the equivalent gain, that a sure gain is favored over a probabilistic gain, and that a probabilistic loss is preferred to a definite loss. One of the dangers of framing effects is that people are often provided with options within the context of only one of the two frames.\n\n\nThis video is targeted to blind users.\n\nAttribution:\nArticle text available under CC-BY-SA\nCreative Commons image source in video", "title": "Framing effect (psychology)", "publishedAt": "2015-10-10T20:18:18Z", "channelTitle": "Audiopedia"}, "id": "52yEQ1Ejtp4", "statistics": {"viewCount": "7126", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "1", "likeCount": "16", "dislikeCount": "9"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1002/fee.2015", "q": "10.1002/fee.2015", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT26M39S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UCV63FScHnShoobfaENC8R_Q", "description": "ISO 14000 is a family of standards related to environmental management that exists to help organizations (a) minimize how their operations (processes, etc.) negatively affect the environment (i.e., cause adverse changes to air, water, or land); (b) comply with applicable laws, regulations, and other environmentally oriented requirements, and (c) continually improve in the above.\nISO 14000 is similar to ISO 9000 quality management in that both pertain to the process of how a product is produced, rather than to the product itself. As with ISO 9000, certification is performed by third-party organizations rather than being awarded by ISO directly. Sexism can affect anyone, but it primarily affects women and girls. It has been linked to stereotypes and gender roles, and may include the belief that one sex or gender is intrinsically superior to another. Extreme sexism may foster sexual harassment, rape, and other forms of sexual violence. Gender discrimination may encompass sexism, and is discrimination toward people based on their gender identity or their gender or sex differences. Gender discrimination is especially defined in terms of workplace inequality.", "channelTitle": "wikipedia tts", "title": "Sexism | Wikipedia audio article", "defaultLanguage": "en"}, "id": "w-Y3DK7zzlA", "statistics": {"viewCount": "188", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "likeCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "1"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1002/fee.2015", "q": "10.1002/fee.2015", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT56M20S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UCGajAfZZjyDnyA7YQU0xpOg", "tags": ["capitals in europe", "cities in albania", "tirana", "wikipedia audio article", "learning by listening", "improves your listening skills", "learn while on the move", "reduce eye strain", "text to speech"], "publishedAt": "2018-11-29T12:08:08Z", "defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "description": "This is an audio version of the Wikipedia Article:\r\nTirana\r\n\r\nListening is a more natural way of learning, when compared to reading. The city is also the capital of the surrounding county of Tirana, one of 12 constituent counties of the country. By air, it is 501 kilometres (311 miles) north of Athens, 613 kilometres (381 miles) southeast of Rome, 153 kilometres (95 miles) southwest of Skopje and 131 kilometres (81 miles) south of Podgorica.\nTirana was founded as a city in 1614, but the region that today corresponds to the city territory has been continuously inhabited since the Bronze Age. As most of Albania, the area was populated by several Illyrian tribes, but had no importance within Illyria. Indeed, it was annexed by Rome and became an integral part of the Roman Empire following the Illyrian Wars. The heritage of that period is still evident and represented by the Mosaics of Tirana. Further later in the 5th and 6th century, a Paleo Christian basilica was built around this site. \nWhen the Roman Empire divided into east and west, its successor the Byzantine Empire took control and included the construction of the Petrel\u00eb Castle, under the reign of Justinian I. Until the 20th century, the city did not attain much significance, when the Congress of Lushnj\u00eb proclaimed it as the country's capital, after the country's declaration of independence in 1912.\nTirana is located in the center of the country surrounded by mountains and hills, with Dajt on the east and a slight valley opening on the northwest, overlooking the Adriatic Sea in the distance. Due to its location within the Tirana plain and the close proximity to the Adriatic Sea, the city is influenced by a mediterranean seasonal climate. It is among the wettest and sunniest cities in Europe, with 2,544 hours of sun per year.Being a primate city, Tirana is considered the economic and cultural hub of Albania, due to its significant location and importance in finance, commerce, media, entertainment, arts, international trade, education, service, research and healthcare. All of the country's largest companies, media and scientific institutions have their headquarters in the city. Tirana is also the seat of power of the Government of Albania, the residences for work of the President and Prime Minister of Albania.", "channelTitle": "wikipedia tts", "title": "Tirana | Wikipedia audio article", "defaultLanguage": "en"}, "id": "pLdZvmATeqs", "statistics": {"viewCount": "97", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "likeCount": "1", "dislikeCount": "1"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1002/fee.2015", "q": "10.1002/fee.2015", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1H1M56S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UCrpY3RRy905oE3SERqJTmBw", "tags": ["artificial intelligence", "formal sciences", "game theory", "john von neumann", "mathematical economics", "wikipedia audio article", "learning by listening", "improves your listening skills", "learn while on the move", "reduce eye strain", "text to speech"], "publishedAt": "2018-11-27T06:05:53Z", "defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "description": "This is an audio version of the Wikipedia Article:\r\nGame theory\r\n\r\nListening is a more natural way of learning, when compared to reading. Written language only began at around 3200 BC, but spoken language has existed long ago.\r\n\r\nLearning by listening is a great way to:\r\n- increases imagination and understanding\r\n- improves your listening skills\r\n- improves your own spoken accent\r\n- learn while on the move\r\n- reduce eye strain\r\n\r\nNow learn the vast amount of general knowledge available on Wikipedia through audio (audio article). You could even learn subconsciously by playing the audio while you are sleeping! If you are planning to listen a lot, you could try using a bone conduction headphone, or a standard speaker instead of an earphone.\r\n\r\nYou can find other Wikipedia audio articles too at:\r\nhttps://www.youtube.com/channel/UCuKfABj2eGyjH3ntPxp4YeQ\r\n\r\nYou can upload your own Wikipedia articles through:\r\nhttps://github.com/nodef/wikipedia-tts\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\"The only true wisdom is in knowing you know nothing.\"\r\n- Socrates\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSUMMARY\r\n=======\r\nGame theory is the study of mathematical models of strategic interaction between rational decision-makers. It has applications in all fields of social science, as well as in logic and computer science. Originally, it addressed zero-sum games, in which one person's gains result in losses for the other participants. Today, game theory applies to a wide range of behavioral relations, and is now an umbrella term for the science of logical decision making in humans, animals, and computers.\nModern game theory began with the idea regarding the existence of mixed-strategy equilibria in two-person zero-sum games and its proof by John von Neumann. Von Neumann's original proof used the Brouwer fixed-point theorem on continuous mappings into compact convex sets, which became a standard method in game theory and mathematical economics. His paper was followed by the 1944 book Theory of Games and Economic Behavior, co-written with Oskar Morgenstern, which considered cooperative games of several players. The second edition of this book provided an axiomatic theory of expected utility, which allowed mathematical statisticians and economists to treat decision-making under uncertainty.\nGame theory was developed extensively in the 1950s by many scholars. It was later explicitly applied to biology in the 1970s, although similar developments go back at least as far as the 1930s. Game theory has been widely recognized as an important tool in many fields. As of  2014, with the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences going to game theorist Jean Tirole, eleven game theorists have won the economics Nobel Prize. John Maynard Smith was awarded the Crafoord Prize for his application of game theory to biology.", "channelTitle": "wikipedia tts", "title": "Game theory | Wikipedia audio article", "defaultLanguage": "en"}, "id": "HDpf0dfQtgY", "statistics": {"viewCount": "65", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "likeCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1002/fee.2015", "q": "10.1002/fee.2015", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT36M42S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UCV63FScHnShoobfaENC8R_Q", "description": "A solar cell (also called a photovoltaic cell) is an electrical device that converts the energy of light directly into electricity by the photovoltaic effect. It is a form of photoelectric cell, defined as a device whose electrical characteristics\u2014e.g. current, voltage, or resistance\u2014vary when exposed to light.\nCells can be described as photovoltaic even when the light source is not necessarily sunlight (lamplight, artificial light, etc.) Photovoltaic cells are used as a photodetector (for example infrared detectors), detecting light or other electromagnetic radiation near the visible range, or measuring light intensity.\n\n\nThis video is targeted to blind users.\n\nAttribution:\nArticle text available under CC-BY-SA\nCreative Commons image source in video", "title": "Solar cell", "publishedAt": "2014-07-22T08:17:44Z", "channelTitle": "Audiopedia"}, "id": "2hdF02c8Hrw", "statistics": {"viewCount": "298", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "likeCount": "1", "dislikeCount": "0"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1002/fee.2015", "q": "10.1002/fee.2015", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT7M4S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UCV63FScHnShoobfaENC8R_Q", "description": "Competitive advantage occurs when an organization acquires or develops an attribute or combination of attributes that allows it to outperform its competitors. These attributes can include access to natural resources, such as high grade ores or inexpensive power, or access to highly trained and skilled personnel human resources. New technologies such as robotics and information technology can provide competitive advantage, whether as a part of the product itself, as an advantage to the making of the product, or as a competitive aid in the business process (for example, better identification and understanding of customers).\n\n\nThis video is targeted to blind users.\n\nAttribution:\nArticle text available under CC-BY-SA\nCreative Commons image source in video", "title": "Competitive advantage", "publishedAt": "2014-08-19T17:23:09Z", "channelTitle": "Audiopedia"}, "id": "HdNTwozZdCA", "statistics": {"viewCount": "331", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "likeCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1002/fee.2015", "q": "10.1002/fee.2015", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT45M34S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UCBnHyctC62ph9p86yBM-I8A", "tags": ["open access", "academic publishing", "electronic publishing", "free culture movement", "open access (publishing)", "open access journals", "scholarly communication", "social movements", "wikipedia audio article", "learning by listening", "improves your listening skills", "learn while on the move", "reduce eye strain", "text to speech"], "publishedAt": "2018-11-28T00:16:09Z", "defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "description": "This is an audio version of the Wikipedia Article:\r\nOpen access\r\n\r\nListening is a more natural way of learning, when compared to reading. Written language only began at around 3200 BC, but spoken language has existed long ago.\r\n\r\nLearning by listening is a great way to:\r\n- increases imagination and understanding\r\n- improves your listening skills\r\n- improves your own spoken accent\r\n- learn while on the move\r\n- reduce eye strain\r\n\r\nNow learn the vast amount of general knowledge available on Wikipedia through audio (audio article). You could even learn subconsciously by playing the audio while you are sleeping! If you are planning to listen a lot, you could try using a bone conduction headphone, or a standard speaker instead of an earphone.\r\n\r\nYou can find other Wikipedia audio articles too at:\r\nhttps://www.youtube.com/channel/UCuKfABj2eGyjH3ntPxp4YeQ\r\n\r\nYou can upload your own Wikipedia articles through:\r\nhttps://github.com/nodef/wikipedia-tts\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\"The only true wisdom is in knowing you know nothing.\"\r\n- Socrates\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSUMMARY\r\n=======\r\nOpen access (OA) refers to research outputs which are distributed online and free of cost or other barriers, and possibly with the addition of a Creative Commons license to promote reuse. Open access can be applied to all forms of published research output, including peer-reviewed and non peer-reviewed academic journal articles, conference papers, theses, book chapters, and monographs.Academic articles (as historically seen in paper-based academic journals) have been the main focus of the movement. Conventional (non-open access) journals cover publishing costs through access tolls such as subscriptions, site licenses or pay-per-view charges. Open access research is advanced by a range of distribution mechanisms and business models. These include:\n\nSelf-archiving - green: After peer review by a journal, the author posts the same content the journal will be publishing to a web site controlled by the author, the research institution that funded or hosted the work, or which has been set up as a central open access repository.\nOpen access journal: The publisher of the journal makes all articles and related content available for free on the journal's web site.\nOpen access journal funded by article processing charges paid by authors or research sponsor - gold\nOpen access journal funded by an academic institution, learned society or a government information center (no publication fees are paid by authors) - platinum, diamond, or gold\nDelayed open-access journals - provide open access after an embargo period, typically 6\u201312 months or longer\nHybrid open access journals at least partially funded by subscriptions, and only provide open access for those individual articles for which the authors (or research sponsor) pay a publication feeAdvantages and disadvantages of open access have generated considerable discussion amongst researchers, academics, librarians, university administrators, funding agencies, government officials, commercial publishers, editorial staff and society publishers. Reactions of existing publishers to open access journal publishing have ranged from moving with enthusiasm to a new open access business model, to experiments with providing as much free or open access as possible, to active lobbying against open access proposals. There are many publishers that started up as open access-only  publishers, such as PLOS, Hindawi Publishing Corporation, Frontiers in... journals, MDPI and BioMed Central.", "channelTitle": "wikipedia tts", "title": "Open access | Wikipedia audio article", "defaultLanguage": "en"}, "id": "NjB2io9X_cA", "statistics": {"viewCount": "7", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "1", "likeCount": "0", NON-PROFIT, EDUCATIONAL OR PERSONAL USE TIPS THE BALANCE IN FAVOUR OF FAIR USE.", "channelTitle": "Castrejo", "title": "What\u00b4s up in Archaeology 19th June 2017:Diseases and Neanderthals"}, "id": "Frapkg6qB54", "statistics": {"viewCount": "1201", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "12", "likeCount": "38", "dislikeCount": "4"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1002/fee.2016", "q": "10.1002/fee.2016", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1H20M25S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UC8PJqHlMhT4p69EzsE2Jz2w", "description": "Los materiales termoel\u00e9ctricos (TE) son ampliamente conocidos por su capacidad de convertir la energ\u00eda t\u00e9rmica en energ\u00eda el\u00e9ctrica y viceversa. La eficiencia termoel\u00e9ctrica est\u00e1 relacionada con la figura de m\u00e9rito zT la cual correlaciona la dependencia entre el coeficiente Sebeeck, la conductividad el\u00e9ctrica y la conductividad t\u00e9rmica. Una de las principales rutas abordadas en el incremento de esta eficiencia TE es precisamente la reducci\u00f3n en la conductividad t\u00e9rmica sin disminuir el coeficiente Sebeeck o la conductividad el\u00e9ctrica. En esta l\u00ednea de investigaci\u00f3n, presentamos un novedoso proceso de fabricaci\u00f3n de nanoestructuras (tanto en pel\u00edcula delgada como nano-mallas) de Silicio-Germanio (Si0.8Ge0.2) a trav\u00e9s de pulverizaci\u00f3n cat\u00f3dica a bajas temperaturas de sustrato. Esta nueva aproximaci\u00f3n, nos permite controlar el tama\u00f1o de poro, espesor y tiempo de dep\u00f3sito en un solo paso, brindando la posibilidad de recubrir grandes \u00e1reas sin necesidad de recurrir a procesos litogr\u00e1ficos o tratamientos t\u00e9rmicos adicionales. As\u00ed mismo, mediante la fabricaci\u00f3n de estas nano-mallas, hemos reducido la conductividad t\u00e9rmica a valores r\u00e9cord, similares a los reportados en la literatura para nano-hilos [1-3].\n\nEn lo que respecta a aplicaciones de materiales TE en temperaturas cercanas al ambiente, recientes investigaciones de seleniuros en volumen han reportado altos valores de eficiencia termoel\u00e9ctrica, debido a sus bajos valores de conductividad t\u00e9rmica y altos valores de coeficiente Sebeeck y conductividad el\u00e9ctrica. Esto se debe fundamentalmente a su inusual comportamiento como semiconductor superi\u00f3nico, lo que ha dado lugar a un nuevo concepto en el campo conocido como \u2018Phonon-liquid electron-crystal - PLEC\u2019. En este sentido, recientemente hemos reportado un significativo avance en la obtenci\u00f3n de nanoestructuras en forma de pel\u00edcula delgada de seleniuro de cobre (Cu2-xSe) [4] y de seleniuro de plata (Ag2Se) \u200b\u200bFigura 1 [5] con alta eficiencia termoel\u00e9ctrica a temperaturas cercanas a la ambiental. Este mejoramiento en la eficiencia TE es obtenido gracias al desarrollo de una nueva t\u00e9cnica de crecimiento la cual hemos llamado pulse controlled reactive magnetron sputtering [4-5]. Esta t\u00e9cnica permite un fino control de la estequiometria, orientaci\u00f3n cristalogr\u00e1fica y eficiencia termoel\u00e9ctrica a bajas temperaturas de sustrato siendo compatible con la fabricaci\u00f3n de pel\u00edculas delgadas sobre sustratos org\u00e1nicos y/o flexibles. Esta nueva adaptaci\u00f3n tecnol\u00f3gica despliega un abanico de nuevas oportunidad y aplicaciones que antes no eran posible mediante la sinterizaci\u00f3n en volumen (en forma de pellets) de estos materiales como se ha venido realizando.\n\n\u200b\u200b\n\u200b\n\u200b\u200b\u200b\u200b\u200bFigura 1. En (a) la figura de m\u00e9rito a traves de los valores de zT obtenidos a temperatura ambiente para diferentes estequiometr\u00edas de Ag / Se. Reportamos con nuestras pel\u00edculas delgadas, valores record con las m\u00e1s altas eficiencia termoelectrica para este material. Esto es debido a la dr\u00e1stica reducci\u00f3n de la conductividad t\u00e9rmica. En (b) se muestra la dependencia de los diferentes valores de zT para Ag2Se a temperatura ambiente en funci\u00f3n de la concentraci\u00f3n de portadores de carga.\u200b\n\n\u200b\u200bReferencias\n\n[1] J.A P\u00e9rez-Taborda et.al, Silicon-Germanium (SiGe) Nanostructures for Thermoelectric Devices: Recent Advances and New Approaches to High Thermoelectric Efficiency, In book, Publisher: InTechOpen, 2017.\n[2] J.A P\u00e9rez-Taborda et.al, Ultra-low thermal conductivities in large-area Si-Ge nanomeshes for thermoelectric applications in Scientific Reports 6:32778, 2016.\n[3] J.A P\u00e9rez-Taborda et.al, Low thermal conductivity and improved thermoelectric performance of nanocrystalline silicon germanium films by sputtering in Nanotechnology 27(17):175401, 2016.\n[4] J.A P\u00e9rez-Taborda et.al, Pulsed Hybrid Reactive Magnetron Sputtering for High zT Cu2Se Thermoelectric Films, Advanced Materials Technologies, 201700012, 2017.\n[5] J. A. Perez-Taborda, O. Caballero-Calero, L. Vera-Londono, F. Briones, M. Martin-Gonzalez, Adv. Energy Mater. 2017, 1702024. https://doi.org/10.1002/aenm.201702024.\n\nDr. Jaime Andr\u00e9s P\u00e9rez Taborda: He received the Engineering Physics degree (Hons.) from the Technological University of Pereira, Colombia, in 2011, and the master's degree in Synchrotron Radiation and Particle Accelerators from the Universitat Aut\u00f2noma de Barcelona in 2013, as well as his Ph.D (Cum laude) from the Institute of Microelectronics of Madrid, Complutense University of Madrid, and Higher Council of Scientific Research CSIC, Spain. He has published research articles and book chapters on various subjects including piezoelectric nanostructures for acoustic wave sensors, nanoengineering new thermoelectric materials with high efficiencies obtained by physical methods, such as sputtering and pulsed laser deposition. Using a very early prototype, this video describes the overarching aim of the framework and shows how it is used in a guideline panel where groups convene to make recommendations, such as those carried out by WHO.\n \nThe framework is now known as the GRADE Evidence to Decision framework. It is embedded as a digital tool in at least two places: \n- in GDT (Guideline Development Tool): https://gradepro.org/ \n- at Epistemonikos (https://ietd.epistemonikos.org/) where you can also see examples\nIt is currently being tailored and used by many organisations around the world, to make their deliberations more structured and transparent.\n\nThere are several scientific articles describing the framework for use in different types of recommendations and decision making, and also describing the full development process:\n\nBASIC DESCRIPTION:\nAlonso-Coello P, Schunemann HJ, Moberg J, Brignardello-Petersen R, Akl EA, Davoli M, et al. GRADE Evidence to Decision (EtD) frameworks: a systematic and transparent approach to making well informed healthcare choices. 1: Introduction. BMJ. 2016;353:i2016.\n\nDESCRIPTION for use in CLINICAL GUIDELINES:\nAlonso-Coello P, Oxman AD, Moberg J, Brignardello-Petersen R, Akl EA, Davoli M, et al. GRADE Evidence to Decision (EtD) frameworks: a systematic and transparent approach to making well informed healthcare choices. 2: Clinical practice guidelines. BMJ. 2016;353:i2089.\n\nDESCRIPTION for use in COVERAGE DECISIONS:\nParmelli E, Amato L, Oxman A, Alonso-Coello P, Brunetti M, Moberg J, et al. GRADE Evidence to Decision (EtD) framework for coverage decisions. International Journal of Technology Assessment in Health Care (accepted).\n\nDESCRIPTION for use in RECOMMENDATIONS or DECISIONS about TESTS:\nSchunemann HJ, Mustafa R, Brozek J, Santesso N, Alonso-Coello P, Guyatt G, et al. GRADE Guidelines: 16. GRADE evidence to decision frameworks for tests in clinical practice and public health. J Clin Epidemiol. 2016;76:89-98.\n\nDESCRIPTION for use in HEALTH SYSTEMS DECISIONS:\nMoberg J, Oxman AD, Rosenbaum SE, Schunemann HJ, Guyatt G, Flottorp S, et al. GRADE Evidence to Decision (EtD) frameworks for health system and public health decisions. Sumbitted to WHO Bulletin. 2017.\n\nDESCRIPTION of FRAMEWORK DEVELOPMENT:\nRosenbaum SE,  Moberg J, Glenton C,  Sch\u00fcnemann HJ,  Lewin S, Akl E, Mustafa RA, Morelli A, Vogel JP, Alonso-Coello P, Rada R, V\u00e1squez J, Parmelli E, G\u00fclmezoglu AM, Flottorp SA, Oxman AD. has changed dramatically since the early 1990s to become the world's largest electricity consumer, passing the United States in 2011. In 2014, it generated 5583TWh, 25% more electricity than the US. In April 1996, an Electric Power Law was implemented, a major event in China's electric power industry. The law set out to promote the development of the electric power industry, to protect legal rights of investors, managers and consumers, and to regulate generation, distribution and consumption. Most of the electricity in China is produced from fossil fuels. In particular, about 79% of annual electricity was produced with coal in China between 2004-2010.\nChina has abundant energy. The country has the world's third-largest coal reserves and massive hydroelectric resources. But there is a geographical mismatch between the location of the coal fields in the north-east and north, hydropower in the south-west, and the fast-growing industrial load centers of the east and south.\n\n\nThis video is targeted to blind users.\n\nAttribution:\nArticle text available under CC-BY-SA\nCreative Commons image source in video", "title": "Electricity sector in China", "publishedAt": "2015-11-25T07:27:38Z", "channelTitle": "Audiopedia"}, "id": "v4XIaIBCpNw", "statistics": {"viewCount": "483", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "1", "likeCount": "4", "dislikeCount": "0"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1002/fee.2016", "q": "10.1002/fee.2016", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT56M20S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UCGajAfZZjyDnyA7YQU0xpOg", "tags": ["capitals in europe", "cities in albania", "tirana", "wikipedia audio article", "learning by listening", "improves your listening skills", "learn while on the move", "reduce eye strain", "text to speech"], "publishedAt": "2018-11-29T12:08:08Z", "defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "description": "This is an audio version of the Wikipedia Article:\r\nTirana\r\n\r\nListening is a more natural way of learning, when compared to reading. The city is also the capital of the surrounding county of Tirana, one of 12 constituent counties of the country. By air, it is 501 kilometres (311 miles) north of Athens, 613 kilometres (381 miles) southeast of Rome, 153 kilometres (95 miles) southwest of Skopje and 131 kilometres (81 miles) south of Podgorica.\nTirana was founded as a city in 1614, but the region that today corresponds to the city territory has been continuously inhabited since the Bronze Age. As most of Albania, the area was populated by several Illyrian tribes, but had no importance within Illyria. Indeed, it was annexed by Rome and became an integral part of the Roman Empire following the Illyrian Wars. The heritage of that period is still evident and represented by the Mosaics of Tirana. Further later in the 5th and 6th century, a Paleo Christian basilica was built around this site. \nWhen the Roman Empire divided into east and west, its successor the Byzantine Empire took control and included the construction of the Petrel\u00eb Castle, under the reign of Justinian I. Until the 20th century, the city did not attain much significance, when the Congress of Lushnj\u00eb proclaimed it as the country's capital, after the country's declaration of independence in 1912.\nTirana is located in the center of the country surrounded by mountains and hills, with Dajt on the east and a slight valley opening on the northwest, overlooking the Adriatic Sea in the distance. Due to its location within the Tirana plain and the close proximity to the Adriatic Sea, the city is influenced by a mediterranean seasonal climate. It is among the wettest and sunniest cities in Europe, with 2,544 hours of sun per year.Being a primate city, Tirana is considered the economic and cultural hub of Albania, due to its significant location and importance in finance, commerce, media, entertainment, arts, international trade, education, service, research and healthcare. All of the country's largest companies, media and scientific institutions have their headquarters in the city. Sexism can affect anyone, but it primarily affects women and girls. It has been linked to stereotypes and gender roles, and may include the belief that one sex or gender is intrinsically superior to another. Extreme sexism may foster sexual harassment, rape, and other forms of sexual violence. Gender discrimination may encompass sexism, and is discrimination toward people based on their gender identity or their gender or sex differences. It has applications in all fields of social science, as well as in logic and computer science. Originally, it addressed zero-sum games, in which one person's gains result in losses for the other participants. Today, game theory applies to a wide range of behavioral relations, and is now an umbrella term for the science of logical decision making in humans, animals, and computers.\nModern game theory began with the idea regarding the existence of mixed-strategy equilibria in two-person zero-sum games and its proof by John von Neumann. Von Neumann's original proof used the Brouwer fixed-point theorem on continuous mappings into compact convex sets, which became a standard method in game theory and mathematical economics. His paper was followed by the 1944 book Theory of Games and Economic Behavior, co-written with Oskar Morgenstern, which considered cooperative games of several players. The second edition of this book provided an axiomatic theory of expected utility, which allowed mathematical statisticians and economists to treat decision-making under uncertainty.\nGame theory was developed extensively in the 1950s by many scholars. It was later explicitly applied to biology in the 1970s, although similar developments go back at least as far as the 1930s. Game theory has been widely recognized as an important tool in many fields. As of  2014, with the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences going to game theorist Jean Tirole, eleven game theorists have won the economics Nobel Prize. John Maynard Smith was awarded the Crafoord Prize for his application of game theory to biology.", "channelTitle": "wikipedia tts", "title": "Game theory | Wikipedia audio article", "defaultLanguage": "en"}, "id": "HDpf0dfQtgY", "statistics": {"viewCount": "65", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "likeCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1002/fee.2016", "q": "10.1002/fee.2016", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT6M32S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UCqsTEykZZCMfAA5wK3mEjyQ", "tags": ["friedrich bergius", "1884 births", "1949 deaths", "german nobel laureates", "german chemists", "german emigrants to argentina", "german scientists", "leipzig university alumni", "nobel laureates in chemistry", "university of breslau alumni", "university of hanover faculty", "wikipedia audio article", "learning by listening", "improves your listening skills", "learn while on the move", "reduce eye strain", "text to speech"], "publishedAt": "2018-11-22T16:51:22Z", "defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "description": "This is an audio version of the Wikipedia Article:\r\nFriedrich Bergius\r\n\r\nListening is a more natural way of learning, when compared to reading. Having worked with IG Farben during World War II, his citizenship came into question following the war, causing him to ultimately flee to Argentina, where he acted as adviser to the Ministry of Industry.Bergius was born near Breslau (Wroc\u0142aw), within the German Empire's Prussian Province of Silesia.", "channelTitle": "wikipedia tts", "title": "Friedrich Bergius | Wikipedia audio article", "defaultLanguage": "en"}, "id": "lYMMDYsFSHA", "statistics": {"viewCount": "72", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "likeCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1002/fee.2016", "q": "10.1002/fee.2016", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT45M34S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UCBnHyctC62ph9p86yBM-I8A", "tags": ["open access", "academic publishing", "electronic publishing", "free culture movement", "open access (publishing)", "open access journals", "scholarly communication", "social movements", "wikipedia audio article", "learning by listening", "improves your listening skills", "learn while on the move", "reduce eye strain", "text to speech"], "publishedAt": "2018-11-28T00:16:09Z", "defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "description": "This is an audio version of the Wikipedia Article:\r\nOpen access\r\n\r\nListening is a more natural way of learning, when compared to reading. Written language only began at around 3200 BC, but spoken language has existed long ago.\r\n\r\nLearning by listening is a great way to:\r\n- increases imagination and understanding\r\n- improves your listening skills\r\n- improves your own spoken accent\r\n- learn while on the move\r\n- reduce eye strain\r\n\r\nNow learn the vast amount of general knowledge available on Wikipedia through audio (audio article). If you are planning to listen a lot, you could try using a bone conduction headphone, or a standard speaker instead of an earphone.\r\n\r\nYou can find other Wikipedia audio articles too at:\r\nhttps://www.youtube.com/channel/UCuKfABj2eGyjH3ntPxp4YeQ\r\n\r\nYou can upload your own Wikipedia articles through:\r\nhttps://github.com/nodef/wikipedia-tts\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\"The only true wisdom is in knowing you know nothing.\"\r\n- Socrates\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSUMMARY\r\n=======\r\nOpen access (OA) refers to research outputs which are distributed online and free of cost or other barriers, and possibly with the addition of a Creative Commons license to promote reuse. Open access can be applied to all forms of published research output, including peer-reviewed and non peer-reviewed academic journal articles, conference papers, theses, book chapters, and monographs.Academic articles (as historically seen in paper-based academic journals) have been the main focus of the movement. Conventional (non-open access) journals cover publishing costs through access tolls such as subscriptions, site licenses or pay-per-view charges. Open access research is advanced by a range of distribution mechanisms and business models. These include:\n\nSelf-archiving - green: After peer review by a journal, the author posts the same content the journal will be publishing to a web site controlled by the author, the research institution that funded or hosted the work, or which has been set up as a central open access repository.\nOpen access journal: The publisher of the journal makes all articles and related content available for free on the journal's web site.\nOpen access journal funded by article processing charges paid by authors or research sponsor - gold\nOpen access journal funded by an academic institution, learned society or a government information center (no publication fees are paid by authors) - platinum, diamond, or gold\nDelayed open-access journals - provide open access after an embargo period, typically 6\u201312 months or longer\nHybrid open access journals at least partially funded by subscriptions, and only provide open access for those individual articles for which the authors (or research sponsor) pay a publication feeAdvantages and disadvantages of open access have generated considerable discussion amongst researchers, academics, librarians, university administrators, funding agencies, government officials, commercial publishers, editorial staff and society publishers. Reactions of existing publishers to open access journal publishing have ranged from moving with enthusiasm to a new open access business model, to experiments with providing as much free or open access as possible, to active lobbying against open access proposals. There are many publishers that started up as open access-only  publishers, such as PLOS, Hindawi Publishing Corporation, Frontiers in... journals, MDPI and BioMed Central.", "channelTitle": "wikipedia tts", "title": "Open access | Wikipedia audio article", "defaultLanguage": "en"}, "id": "NjB2io9X_cA", "statistics": {"viewCount": "7", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "1", "likeCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1002/fee.2017", "q": "10.1002/fee.2017", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT4M57S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UCBGGq4LmkhdOvavIXLbktLA", "description": "Title : Sustainable and Flexible Super Capacitor based on Office Waste Paper Electrode\nBy : Universiti Sains Malaysia\n\nToday's super capacitors are relatively expensive, often too expensive for adequate applications. To produce affordable devices, low material and production costs are crucial. Therefore, inexpensive and environmentally friendly materials in combination with proven paper-making technologies is use to produce super capacitors. The idea is to use low-cost materials like graphite and paper as active and passive components in the devices. In this study, we developed a sustainable and \ufb02exible electrode by using the of\ufb01ce waste paper \ufb01bers reduced graphene oxide-manganese dioxide (PF-RGO-MnO2) \ufb01lm. The PFs with light weight, hygroscopic, and porous properties are not only served as a great low-cost and \ufb02exible substrate but also important to improve the ion diffusion and electron transfer rate between the electrodes and electrolytes. Mono-dispersed of PFs are obtained from the of\ufb01ce waste paper with ultra-sonication, wash, and activation procedure. As a result, owing to the excellent mechanical \ufb02exibility of PFs, great electrical conductivity of RGO sheets, and high electro-activity of MnO2-nanowires, the as-prepared hybrid PFRGOMnO2 electrode exhibits excellent rate capability and high speci\ufb01c capacitance of 410 F g\u22121 at 0.8 A g\u22121. The assembled solid-state symmetric supercapacitors exhibit high energy density (19.6 Wh kg\u22121 at 400 W kg\u22121) and excellent cycling stability of 85.3% retention even after 2000 folding and bending cycles. The development of an alternative super capacitor electrode material from waste paper serves two main purposes that are helps with waste disposal; converting waste to a useful product and provides an economic argument for the substantiality of super capacitor technology.", "title": "NACES2019:TVC_Sustainable and Flexible Super Capacitor based on Office Waste Paper_USM_Team1", "publishedAt": "2019-09-09T13:40:10Z", "channelTitle": "DenZsenpai"}, "id": "NT7R9trlWTM", "statistics": {"viewCount": "57", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "likeCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1002/fee.2017", "q": "10.1002/fee.2017", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT37M57S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UCS9HCceuRHm8GIraxFm86tA", "tags": ["health education", "health", "medical", "medical education", "education", "project echo", "university of idaho"], "publishedAt": "2019-08-26T19:45:41Z", "description": "Perry Brown, MD\n01/24/2109\nLearn more at https://www.uidaho.edu/echo\nVideo recordings of past ECHO sessions are not designated for CME credit.", "channelTitle": "ECHO Idaho", "title": "Opiate and Chronic Pain: Pediatric Considersations"}, "id": "EwxIBrR0rz0", "statistics": {"viewCount": "9", "favoriteCount": "0", "likeCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1002/fee.2017", "q": "10.1002/fee.2017", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT7M"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UCtzcEsZvRJoPqHn4CRS_Cug", "tags": ["objectives of research", "research and development", "Shodh", "Talks", "mri contrast agents", "nanotechnology"], "publishedAt": "2020-02-26T05:20:07Z", "defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "description": "Gadolinium-based contrast agents (GBCA) additionally alluded to as contrast media are chemical substances utilized to separate ordinary and malignant growth cells. A very short road from Arrhenius to Marcus to the Franck Condon Weighted Density of States in the Marcus Inverted Region. Learning objectives:\n\n\u2022 The Arrhenius equation and the Classical Marcus equation have the same foundations.\n\u2022 In the Semi-Classical Marcus equation the pre-exponential factor only contains the solvent reorganization energy. The exponential term incorporates a specific vibration that mediates the electron transfer and is important for the vibronic coupling.\n\u2022 Molecular vibrations can mix into electronic transitions, thereby playing an important role in transfer processes.\n\n\u2022 Photochemistry has a direct link with quantum chemistry.\n\u2022 Intermolecular (or interchromophoric) interactions in the excited state can lead to electronic interactions enabling transfer processes.\n\n\nFor more information see:\nElectron Transfer Reactions in Chemistry: Theory and Experiment (Nobel Lecture)\u2020\nProf. Dr. Rudolph A. Lee also shows 8 of her favorite budget-friendly, plant-based picks!", "title": "Plant-Based on a Budget! | Exam Room Live | May 7th, 2020", "publishedAt": "2020-05-07T16:45:01Z", "channelTitle": "Physicians Committee"}, "id": "Gxal3z5Ztz0", "statistics": {"viewCount": "6562", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "49", "likeCount": "370", "dislikeCount": "11"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1002/fee.2017", "q": "10.1002/fee.2017", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT7M8S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UC4Aq2sSeNrb6-n6Ib4hR4Mw", "tags": ["THUNK", "terrorism", "psychology", "understanding"], "publishedAt": "2017-11-30T05:07:12Z", "defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "description": "\u201cI will *never* understand why people X.\u201d Oh really? Let\u2019s turn that dial up to 11 and see what happens.\n\n-Links for the Curious-\nIn case you\u2019re wondering why I didn\u2019t include a reference to the Netflix show \u201cMindhunter\u201d (a fictional drama based on the origins of FBI profiling & forensic psychology of serial killers), there\u2019s a growing body of criticism regarding the methods & rigor of those techniques, & I didn\u2019t want to get bogged down hashing out details. Pretty much all of the criminal psychology used in law enforcement today assumes the central premise of this video (that even horrifyingly divergent minds can be simulated & understood to some degree), but it\u2019s possible that the FBI\u2019s whole classification system is pseudoscience - https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2007/11/12/dangerous-minds \n \nPsychopathology of terrorists (Piccinni et al, 2017) - https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28931447\n\nPatterns of Thinking in Militant Extremism (Saucier et al, 2009) - http://pages.uoregon.edu/gsaucier/Saucier_et_al_Patterns_of_Thinking.pdf\n \nInside the Terrorist Mind (Schaefer, 2007) - https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/inside-the-terrorist-mind/\n \nPsychology of Terrorism (Borum, 2004) - http://scholarcommons.usf.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1570&context=mhlp_facpub\n \nPsychological Vulnerabilities and Propensities for Involvement in Violent Extremism (Borum, 2014) - http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/bsl.2110/full\n\nGenesis of Suicide Terrorism (Atran, 2003) - http://science.sciencemag.org/content/299/5612/1534.full", "channelTitle": "THUNK", "title": "132. On Understanding Others | THUNK"}, "id": "wxO2FVh18a8", "statistics": {"viewCount": "3215", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "78", "likeCount": "289", "dislikeCount": "2"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1002/fee.2017", "q": "10.1002/fee.2017", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT2H24M31S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UCN0tzbRQlHJyiWmQB8uUjbw", "description": "", "title": "Si\u00eau", "publishedAt": "2020-04-15T10:52:08Z", "channelTitle": "Ho\u00e0i Giang"}, "id": "XE7r8_uZzTg", "statistics": {"viewCount": "13", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "likeCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1002/fee.2017", "q": "10.1002/fee.2017", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1H20M25S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UC8PJqHlMhT4p69EzsE2Jz2w", "description": "Los materiales termoel\u00e9ctricos (TE) son ampliamente conocidos por su capacidad de convertir la energ\u00eda t\u00e9rmica en energ\u00eda el\u00e9ctrica y viceversa. La eficiencia termoel\u00e9ctrica est\u00e1 relacionada con la figura de m\u00e9rito zT la cual correlaciona la dependencia entre el coeficiente Sebeeck, la conductividad el\u00e9ctrica y la conductividad t\u00e9rmica. Una de las principales rutas abordadas en el incremento de esta eficiencia TE es precisamente la reducci\u00f3n en la conductividad t\u00e9rmica sin disminuir el coeficiente Sebeeck o la conductividad el\u00e9ctrica. En esta l\u00ednea de investigaci\u00f3n, presentamos un novedoso proceso de fabricaci\u00f3n de nanoestructuras (tanto en pel\u00edcula delgada como nano-mallas) de Silicio-Germanio (Si0.8Ge0.2) a trav\u00e9s de pulverizaci\u00f3n cat\u00f3dica a bajas temperaturas de sustrato. Esta nueva aproximaci\u00f3n, nos permite controlar el tama\u00f1o de poro, espesor y tiempo de dep\u00f3sito en un solo paso, brindando la posibilidad de recubrir grandes \u00e1reas sin necesidad de recurrir a procesos litogr\u00e1ficos o tratamientos t\u00e9rmicos adicionales. As\u00ed mismo, mediante la fabricaci\u00f3n de estas nano-mallas, hemos reducido la conductividad t\u00e9rmica a valores r\u00e9cord, similares a los reportados en la literatura para nano-hilos [1-3].\n\nEn lo que respecta a aplicaciones de materiales TE en temperaturas cercanas al ambiente, recientes investigaciones de seleniuros en volumen han reportado altos valores de eficiencia termoel\u00e9ctrica, debido a sus bajos valores de conductividad t\u00e9rmica y altos valores de coeficiente Sebeeck y conductividad el\u00e9ctrica. Esto se debe fundamentalmente a su inusual comportamiento como semiconductor superi\u00f3nico, lo que ha dado lugar a un nuevo concepto en el campo conocido como \u2018Phonon-liquid electron-crystal - PLEC\u2019. En este sentido, recientemente hemos reportado un significativo avance en la obtenci\u00f3n de nanoestructuras en forma de pel\u00edcula delgada de seleniuro de cobre (Cu2-xSe) [4] y de seleniuro de plata (Ag2Se) \u200b\u200bFigura 1 [5] con alta eficiencia termoel\u00e9ctrica a temperaturas cercanas a la ambiental. Este mejoramiento en la eficiencia TE es obtenido gracias al desarrollo de una nueva t\u00e9cnica de crecimiento la cual hemos llamado pulse controlled reactive magnetron sputtering [4-5]. Esta t\u00e9cnica permite un fino control de la estequiometria, orientaci\u00f3n cristalogr\u00e1fica y eficiencia termoel\u00e9ctrica a bajas temperaturas de sustrato siendo compatible con la fabricaci\u00f3n de pel\u00edculas delgadas sobre sustratos org\u00e1nicos y/o flexibles. Esta nueva adaptaci\u00f3n tecnol\u00f3gica despliega un abanico de nuevas oportunidad y aplicaciones que antes no eran posible mediante la sinterizaci\u00f3n en volumen (en forma de pellets) de estos materiales como se ha venido realizando.\n\n\u200b\u200b\n\u200b\n\u200b\u200b\u200b\u200b\u200bFigura 1. En (a) la figura de m\u00e9rito a traves de los valores de zT obtenidos a temperatura ambiente para diferentes estequiometr\u00edas de Ag / Se. Reportamos con nuestras pel\u00edculas delgadas, valores record con las m\u00e1s altas eficiencia termoelectrica para este material. Esto es debido a la dr\u00e1stica reducci\u00f3n de la conductividad t\u00e9rmica. En (b) se muestra la dependencia de los diferentes valores de zT para Ag2Se a temperatura ambiente en funci\u00f3n de la concentraci\u00f3n de portadores de carga.\u200b\n\n\u200b\u200bReferencias\n\n[1] J.A P\u00e9rez-Taborda et.al, Silicon-Germanium (SiGe) Nanostructures for Thermoelectric Devices: Recent Advances and New Approaches to High Thermoelectric Efficiency, In book, Publisher: InTechOpen, 2017.\n[2] J.A P\u00e9rez-Taborda et.al, Ultra-low thermal conductivities in large-area Si-Ge nanomeshes for thermoelectric applications in Scientific Reports 6:32778, 2016.\n[3] J.A P\u00e9rez-Taborda et.al, Low thermal conductivity and improved thermoelectric performance of nanocrystalline silicon germanium films by sputtering in Nanotechnology 27(17):175401, 2016.\n[4] J.A P\u00e9rez-Taborda et.al, Pulsed Hybrid Reactive Magnetron Sputtering for High zT Cu2Se Thermoelectric Films, Advanced Materials Technologies, 201700012, 2017.\n[5] J. A. Perez-Taborda, O. Caballero-Calero, L. Vera-Londono, F. Briones, M. Martin-Gonzalez, Adv. Energy Mater. 2017, 1702024. https://doi.org/10.1002/aenm.201702024.\n\nDr. Jaime Andr\u00e9s P\u00e9rez Taborda: He received the Engineering Physics degree (Hons.) from the Technological University of Pereira, Colombia, in 2011, and the master's degree in Synchrotron Radiation and Particle Accelerators from the Universitat Aut\u00f2noma de Barcelona in 2013, as well as his Ph.D (Cum laude) from the Institute of Microelectronics of Madrid, Complutense University of Madrid, and Higher Council of Scientific Research CSIC, Spain. He has published research articles and book chapters on various subjects including piezoelectric nanostructures for acoustic wave sensors, nanoengineering new thermoelectric materials with high efficiencies obtained by physical methods, such as sputtering and pulsed laser deposition. In addition, he is also a co-founder and President of the Colombian Society of Physics Engineering.", "title": "Nanoestructuras termoel\u00e9ctricas de Alta eficiencia.  27 - Feb - 2018", "publishedAt": "2018-03-09T02:08:15Z", "channelTitle": "Coloquio Licenciatura en F\u00edsica"}, "id": "J4znkibyndQ", "statistics": {"viewCount": "76", "favoriteCount": "0", "commentCount": "0", "likeCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0"}}]}, {"idx_paper": "10.1002/fee.2017", "q": "10.1002/fee.2017", "items": [{"contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1H23S"}, "snippet": {"channelId": "UCkgd7WjHdEdCH6CE_d0gJNQ", "publishedAt": "2020-06-18T21:08:42Z", "defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "description": "Unpack what experts truly mean when they speak about disease prevention. Using a very early prototype, this video describes the overarching aim of the framework and shows how it is used in a guideline panel where groups convene to make recommendations, such as those carried out by WHO.\n \nThe framework is now known as the GRADE Evidence to Decision framework. It is embedded as a digital tool in at least two places: \n- in GDT (Guideline Development Tool): https://gradepro.org/ \n- at Epistemonikos (https://ietd.epistemonikos.org/) where you can also see examples\nIt is currently being tailored and used by many organisations around the world, to make their deliberations more structured and transparent.\n\nThere are several scientific articles describing the framework for use in different types of recommendations and decision making, and also describing the full development process:\n\nBASIC DESCRIPTION:\nAlonso-Coello P, Schunemann HJ, Moberg J, Brignardello-Petersen R, Akl EA, Davoli M, et al. GRADE Evidence to Decision (EtD) frameworks: a systematic and transparent approach to making well informed healthcare choices. 1: Introduction. BMJ. 2016;353:i2016.\n\nDESCRIPTION for use in CLINICAL GUIDELINES:\nAlonso-Coello P, Oxman AD, Moberg J, Brignardello-Petersen R, Akl EA, Davoli M, et al. GRADE Evidence to Decision (EtD) frameworks: a systematic and transparent approach to making well informed healthcare choices. 2: Clinical practice guidelines. BMJ. 2016;353:i2089.\n\nDESCRIPTION for use in COVERAGE DECISIONS:\nParmelli E, Amato L, Oxman A, Alonso-Coello P, Brunetti M, Moberg J, et al. GRADE Evidence to Decision (EtD) framework for coverage decisions. International Journal of Technology Assessment in Health Care (accepted).\n\nDESCRIPTION for use in RECOMMENDATIONS or DECISIONS about TESTS:\nSchunemann HJ, Mustafa R, Brozek J, Santesso N, Alonso-Coello P, Guyatt G, et al. GRADE Guidelines: 16. GRADE evidence to decision frameworks for tests in clinical practice and public health. J Clin Epidemiol. 2016;76:89-98.\n\nDESCRIPTION for use in HEALTH SYSTEMS DECISIONS:\nMoberg J, Oxman AD, Rosenbaum SE, Schunemann HJ, Guyatt G, Flottorp S, et al. GRADE Evidence to Decision (EtD) frameworks for health system and public health decisions.
